passages.en: Perhaps we may go on with them to principles, but we shall find them unable to get established in those along with us.

passages.zh: 可與立，未可與權。」
passages.en: Or if we may get so established along with them, we shall find them unable to weigh occurring events along with us."

passages.zh: 「唐棣之華，偏其反而。豈不爾思？室是遠而。」
passages.en: "How the flowers of the aspen-plum flutter and turn! Do I not think of you? But your house is distant."

passages.zh: 子曰：「未之思也，夫何遠之有？」
passages.en: The Master said, "It is the want of thought about it. How is it distant?"

passages.zh: 孔子於鄉黨，恂恂如也，似不能言者。
passages.en: Confucius, in his village, looked simple and sincere, and as if he were not able to speak.

passages.zh: 其在宗廟朝廷，便便言，唯謹爾。
passages.en: When he was in the prince's ancestral temple, or in the court, he spoke minutely on every point, but cautiously.

passages.zh: 朝，與下大夫言，侃侃如也；
passages.en: When he was waiting at court, in speaking with the great officers of the lower grade, he spoke freely, but in a straightforward manner;

passages.zh: 與上大夫言，誾誾如也。
passages.en: in speaking with those of the higher grade, he did so blandly, but precisely.

passages.zh: 君在，踧踖如也。與與如也。
passages.en: When the ruler was present, his manner displayed respectful uneasiness; it was grave, but self-possessed.

passages.zh: 君召使擯，色勃如也，足躩如也。
passages.en: When the prince called him to employ him in the reception of a visitor, his countenance appeared to change, and his legs to move forward with difficulty.

passages.zh: 揖所與立，左右手。衣前後，襜如也。
passages.en: He inclined himself to the other officers among whom he stood, moving his left or right arm, as their position required, but keeping the skirts of his robe before and behind evenly adjusted.

passages.zh: 趨進，翼如也。
passages.en: He hastened forward, with his arms like the wings of a bird.

passages.zh: 賓退，必復命曰：「賓不顧矣。」
passages.en: When the guest had retired, he would report to the prince, "The visitor is not turning round any more."

passages.zh: 入公門，鞠躬如也，如不容。
passages.en: When he entered the palace gate, he seemed to bend his body, as if it were not sufficient to admit him.

passages.zh: 立不中門，行不履閾。
passages.en: When he was standing, he did not occupy the middle of the gateway; when he passed in or out, he did not tread upon the threshold.

passages.zh: 過位，色勃如也，足躩如也，其言似不足者。
passages.en: When he was passing the vacant place of the prince, his countenance appeared to change, and his legs to bend under him, and his words came as if he hardly had breath to utter them.

passages.zh: 攝齊升堂，鞠躬如也，屏氣似不息者。
passages.en: He ascended the reception hall, holding up his robe with both his hands, and his body bent; holding in his breath also, as if he dared not breathe.

passages.zh: 出，降一等，逞顏色，怡怡如也。
passages.en: When he came out from the audience, as soon as he had descended one step, he began to relax his countenance, and had a satisfied look.

passages.zh: 沒階趨進，翼如也。
passages.en: When he had got the bottom of the steps, he advanced rapidly to his place, with his arms like wings,

passages.zh: 復其位，踧踖如也。
passages.en: and on occupying it, his manner still showed respectful uneasiness.

passages.zh: 執圭，鞠躬如也，如不勝。
passages.en: When he was carrying the scepter of his ruler, he seemed to bend his body, as if he were not able to bear its weight.

passages.zh: 上如揖，下如授。
passages.en: He did not hold it higher than the position of the hands in making a bow, nor lower than their position in giving anything to another.

passages.zh: 勃如戰色，足蹜蹜，如有循。
passages.en: His countenance seemed to change, and look apprehensive, and he dragged his feet along as if they were held by something to the ground.

passages.zh: 享禮，有容色。
passages.en: In presenting the presents with which he was charged, he wore a placid appearance.

passages.zh: 私覿，愉愉如也。
passages.en: At his private audience, he looked highly pleased.

passages.zh: 君子不以紺緅飾。紅紫不以為褻服。
passages.en: The superior man did not use a deep purple, or a puce color, in the ornaments of his dress. Even in his undress, he did not wear anything of a red or reddish color.

passages.zh: 當暑，袗絺綌，必表而出之。
passages.en: In warm weather, he had a single garment either of coarse or fine texture, but he wore it displayed over an inner garment.

passages.zh: 緇衣羔裘，素衣麑裘，黃衣狐裘。
passages.en: Over lamb's fur he wore a garment of black; over fawn's fur one of white; and over fox's fur one of yellow.

passages.zh: 褻裘長。短右袂。
passages.en: The fur robe of his undress was long, with the right sleeve short.

passages.zh: 必有寢衣，長一身有半。
passages.en: He required his sleeping dress to be half as long again as his body.

passages.zh: 狐貉之厚以居。
passages.en: When staying at home, he used thick furs of the fox or the badger.

passages.zh: 去喪，無所不佩。
passages.en: When he put off mourning, he wore all the appendages of the girdle.

passages.zh: 非帷裳，必殺之。
passages.en: His undergarment, except when it was required to be of the curtain shape, was made of silk cut narrow above and wide below.

passages.zh: 羔裘玄冠不以弔。
passages.en: He did not wear lamb's fur or a black cap on a visit of condolence.

passages.zh: 吉月，必朝服而朝。
passages.en: On the first day of the month he put on his court robes, and presented himself at court.

passages.zh: 齊，必有明衣，布。
passages.en: When fasting, he thought it necessary to have his clothes brightly clean and made of linen cloth.

passages.zh: 齊，必變食，居必遷坐。
passages.en: When fasting, he thought it necessary to change his food, and also to change the place where he commonly sat in the apartment.

passages.zh: 食不厭精，膾不厭細。
passages.en: He did not dislike to have his rice finely cleaned, nor to have his mince meat cut quite small.

passages.zh: 食饐而餲，魚餒而肉敗，不食。
passages.en: He did not eat rice which had been injured by heat or damp and turned sour, nor fish or flesh which was gone.

passages.zh: 色惡，不食。臭惡，不食。失飪，不食。不時，不食。
passages.en: He did not eat what was discolored, or what was of a bad flavor, nor anything which was ill-cooked, or was not in season.

passages.zh: 割不正，不食。不得其醬，不食。
passages.en: He did not eat meat which was not cut properly, nor what was served without its proper sauce.

passages.zh: 肉雖多，不使勝食氣。
passages.en: Though there might be a large quantity of meat, he would not allow what he took to exceed the due proportion for the rice.

passages.zh: 惟酒無量，不及亂。
passages.en: It was only in wine that he laid down no limit for himself, but he did not allow himself to be confused by it.

passages.zh: 沽酒市脯不食。
passages.en: He did not partake of wine and dried meat bought in the market.

passages.zh: 不撤薑食。不多食。
passages.en: He was never without ginger when he ate. He did not eat much.

passages.zh: 祭於公，不宿肉。
passages.en: When he had been assisting at the prince's sacrifice, he did not keep the flesh which he received overnight.

passages.zh: 祭肉不出三日。出三日，不食之矣。
passages.en: The flesh of his family sacrifice he did not keep over three days. If kept over three days, people could not eat it.

passages.zh: 食不語，寢不言。
passages.en: When eating, he did not converse. When in bed, he did not speak.

passages.zh: 雖疏食菜羹，瓜祭，必齊如也。
passages.en: Although his food might be coarse rice and vegetable soup, he would offer a little of it in sacrifice with a grave, respectful air.

passages.zh: 席不正，不坐。
passages.en: If his mat was not straight, he did not sit on it.

passages.zh: 鄉人飲酒，杖者出，斯出矣。
passages.en: When the villagers were drinking together, upon those who carried staffs going out, he went out immediately after.

passages.zh: 鄉人儺，朝服而立於阼階。
passages.en: When the villagers were going through their ceremonies to drive away pestilential influences, he put on his court robes and stood on the eastern steps.

passages.zh: 問人於他邦，再拜而送之。
passages.en: When he was sending complimentary inquiries to any one in another state, he bowed twice as he escorted the messenger away.

passages.zh: 康子饋藥，拜而受之。
passages.en: Ji Kang having sent him a present of physic, he bowed and received it,

passages.zh: 曰：「丘未達，不敢嘗。」
passages.en: saying, "I do not know it. I dare not taste it."

passages.zh: 廄焚。子退朝，曰：「傷人乎？」不問馬。
passages.en: The stable being burned down, when he was at court, on his return he said, "Has any man been hurt?" He did not ask about the horses.

passages.zh: 君賜食，必正席先嘗之；
passages.en: When the prince sent him a gift of cooked meat, he would adjust his mat, first taste it, and then give it away to others.

passages.zh: 君賜腥，必熟而薦之；
passages.en: When the prince sent him a gift of undressed meat, he would have it cooked, and offer it to the spirits of his ancestors.

passages.zh: 君賜生，必畜之。
passages.en: When the prince sent him a gift of a living animal, he would keep it alive.

passages.zh: 侍食於君，君祭，先飯。
passages.en: When he was in attendance on the prince and joining in the entertainment, the prince only sacrificed. He first tasted everything.

passages.zh: 疾，君視之，東首，加朝服，拖紳。
passages.en: When he was ill and the prince came to visit him, he had his head to the east, made his court robes be spread over him, and drew his girdle across them.

passages.zh: 君命召，不俟駕行矣。
passages.en: When the prince's order called him, without waiting for his carriage to be yoked, he went at once.

passages.zh: 入太廟，每事問。
passages.en: When he entered the ancestral temple of the state, he asked about everything.

passages.zh: 朋友死，無所歸。曰：「於我殯。」
passages.en: When any of his friends died, if he had no relations who could be depended on for the necessary offices, he would say, "I will bury him."

passages.zh: 朋友之饋，雖車馬，非祭肉，不拜。
passages.en: When a friend sent him a present, though it might be a carriage and horses, he did not bow. The only present for which he bowed was that of the flesh of sacrifice.

passages.zh: 寢不尸，居不容。
passages.en: In bed, he did not lie like a corpse. At home, he did not put on any formal deportment.

passages.zh: 見齊衰者，雖狎，必變。
passages.en: When he saw any one in a mourning dress, though it might be an acquaintance, he would change countenance;

passages.zh: 見冕者與瞽者，雖褻，必以貌。
passages.en: when he saw any one wearing the cap of full dress, or a blind person, though he might be in his undress, he would salute him in a ceremonious manner.

passages.zh: 凶服者式之。式負版者。
passages.en: To any person in mourning he bowed forward to the crossbar of his carriage; he bowed in the same way to any one bearing the tables of population.

passages.zh: 有盛饌，必變色而作。
passages.en: When he was at an entertainment where there was an abundance of provisions set before him, he would change countenance and rise up.

passages.zh: 迅雷風烈，必變。
passages.en: On a sudden clap of thunder, or a violent wind, he would change countenance.

passages.zh: 升車，必正立執綏。
passages.en: When he was about to mount his carriage, he would stand straight, holding the cord.

passages.zh: 車中，不內顧，不疾言，不親指。
passages.en: When he was in the carriage, he did not turn his head quite round, he did not talk hastily, he did not point with his hands.

passages.zh: 色斯舉矣，翔而後集。
passages.en: Seeing the countenance, it instantly rises. It flies round, and by and by settles.

passages.zh: 曰：「山梁雌雉，時哉！時哉！」
passages.en: The Master said, "There is the hen-pheasant on the hill bridge. At its season! At its season!"

passages.zh: 子路共之，三嗅而作。
passages.en: Zi Lu made a motion to it. Thrice it smelled him and then rose.

passages.zh: 子曰：「先進於禮樂，野人也；
passages.en: The Master said, "The men of former times in the matters of ceremonies and music were rustics, it is said,

passages.zh: 後進於禮樂，君子也。
passages.en: while the men of these latter times, in ceremonies and music, are accomplished gentlemen.

passages.zh: 如用之，則吾從先進。」
passages.en: If I have occasion to use those things, I follow the men of former times."

passages.zh: 子曰：「從我於陳、蔡者，皆不及門也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Of those who were with me in Chen and Cai, there are none to be found to enter my door."

passages.zh: 德行：顏淵，閔子騫，冉伯牛，仲弓。言語：宰我，子貢。政事：冉有，季路。文學：子游，子夏。
passages.en: Distinguished for their virtuous principles and practice, there were Yan Yuan, Min Zi Qian, Ran Bo Niu, and Zhong Gong; for their ability in speech, Zai Wo and Zi Gong; for their administrative talents, Ran You and Ji Lu; for their literary acquirements, Zi You and Zi Xia.

passages.zh: 子曰：「回也非助我者也，於吾言無所不說。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Hui gives me no assistance. There is nothing that I say in which he does not delight."

passages.zh: 子曰：「孝哉閔子騫！人不間於其父母昆弟之言。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Filial indeed is Min Zi Qian! Other people say nothing of him different from the report of his parents and brothers."

passages.zh: 南容三復白圭，孔子以其兄之子妻之。
passages.en: Nan Rong was frequently repeating the lines about a white scepter stone. Confucius gave him the daughter of his elder brother to wife.

passages.zh: 季康子問：「弟子孰為好學？」
passages.en: Ji Kang asked which of the disciples loved to learn.

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「有顏回者好學，不幸短命死矣！今也則亡。」
passages.en: Confucius replied to him, "There was Yan Hui; he loved to learn. Unfortunately his appointed time was short, and he died. Now there is no one who loves to learn, as he did."

passages.zh: 顏淵死，顏路請子之車以為之椁。
passages.en: When Yan Yuan died, Yan Lu begged the carriage of the Master to sell and get an outer shell for his son's coffin.

passages.zh: 子曰：「才不才，亦各言其子也。
passages.en: The Master said, "Whether he has talents or has not talents, everyone calls his son his son.

passages.zh: 鯉也死，有棺而無椁。
passages.en: There was Li; when he died, he had a coffin but no outer shell.

passages.zh: 吾不徒行以為之椁。以吾從大夫之後，不可徒行也。」
passages.en: I would not walk on foot to get a shell for him, because, having followed in the rear of the great officers, it was not proper that I should walk on foot."

passages.zh: 顏淵死。子曰：「噫！天喪予！天喪予！」
passages.en: When Yan Yuan died, the Master said, "Alas! Heaven is destroying me! Heaven is destroying me!"

passages.zh: 顏淵死，子哭之慟。
passages.en: When Yan Yuan died, the Master bewailed him exceedingly,

passages.zh: 從者曰：「子慟矣。」
passages.en: and the disciples who were with him said, "Master, your grief is excessive!"

passages.zh: 曰：「有慟乎？非夫人之為慟而誰為！」
passages.en: "Is it excessive?" said he. "If I am not to mourn bitterly for this man, for whom should I mourn?"

passages.zh: 顏淵死，門人欲厚葬之，子曰：「不可。」
passages.en: When Yan Yuan died, the disciples wished to give him a great funeral, and the Master said, "You may not do so."

passages.zh: 門人厚葬之。
passages.en: The disciples did bury him in great style.

passages.zh: 子曰：「回也視予猶父也，予不得視猶子也。非我也，夫二三子也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Hui behaved towards me as his father. I have not been able to treat him as my son. The fault is not mine; it belongs to you, O disciples."

passages.zh: 季路問事鬼神。
passages.en: Ji Lu asked about serving the spirits of the dead.

passages.zh: 子曰：「未能事人，焉能事鬼？」
passages.en: The Master said, "While you are not able to serve men, how can you serve their spirits?"

passages.zh: 敢問死。曰：「未知生，焉知死？」
passages.en: Ji Lu added, "I venture to ask about death?" He was answered, "While you do not know life, how can you know about death?"

passages.zh: 閔子侍側，誾誾如也；
passages.en: The disciple Min was standing by his side, looking bland and precise;

passages.zh: 子路，行行如也；
passages.en: Zi Lu, looking bold and soldierly;

passages.zh: 冉有、子貢，侃侃如也。子樂。
passages.en: Ran You and Zi Gong, with a free and straightforward manner. The Master was pleased.

passages.zh: 「若由也，不得其死然。」
passages.en: He said, "You there - he will not die a natural death."

passages.zh: 魯人為長府。
passages.en: Some parties in Lu were going to take down and rebuild the Long Treasury.

passages.zh: 閔子騫曰：「仍舊貫，如之何？何必改作？」
passages.en: Min Zi Qian said, "Suppose it were to be repaired after its old style; why must it be altered and made anew?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「夫人不言，言必有中。」
passages.en: The Master said, "This man seldom speaks; when he does, he is sure to hit the point."

passages.zh: 子曰：「由之瑟奚為於丘之門？」
passages.en: The Master said, "What has the lute of You to do in my door?"

passages.zh: 門人不敬子路。
passages.en: The other disciples began not to respect Zi Lu.

passages.zh: 子曰：「由也升堂矣，未入於室也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "You has ascended to the hall, though he has not yet passed into the inner apartments."

passages.zh: 子貢問：「師與商也孰賢？」
passages.en: Zi Gong asked which of the two, Shi or Shang, was the superior.

passages.zh: 子曰：「師也過，商也不及。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Shi goes beyond the due mean, and Shang does not come up to it."

passages.zh: 曰：「然則師愈與？」
passages.en: "Then," said Zi Gong, "the superiority is with Shi, I suppose."

passages.zh: 子曰：「過猶不及。」
passages.en: The Master said, "To go beyond is as wrong as to fall short."

passages.zh: 季氏富於周公，而求也為之聚斂而附益之。
passages.en: The head of the Ji family was richer than the duke of Zhou had been, and yet Qiu collected his imposts for him, and increased his wealth.

passages.zh: 子曰：「非吾徒也。小子鳴鼓而攻之，可也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He is no disciple of mine. My little children, beat the drum and assail him."

passages.zh: 柴也愚，參也魯，師也辟，由也喭。
passages.en: Chai is simple. Shen is dull. Shi is specious. You is coarse.

passages.zh: 子曰：「回也其庶乎，屢空。
passages.en: The Master said, "There is Hui! He has nearly attained to perfect virtue. He is often in want.

passages.zh: 賜不受命，而貨殖焉，億則屢中。」
passages.en: Ci does not acquiesce in the appointments of Heaven, and his goods are increased by him. Yet his judgments are often correct."

passages.zh: 子張問善人之道。
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked what were the characteristics of the good man.

passages.zh: 子曰：「不踐跡，亦不入於室。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He does not tread in the footsteps of others, but moreover, he does not enter the chamber of the sage."

passages.zh: 子曰：「論篤是與，君子者乎？色莊者乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "If, because a man's discourse appears solid and sincere, we allow him to be a good man, is he really a superior man? or is his gravity only in appearance?"

passages.zh: 子路問：「聞斯行諸？」
passages.en: Zi Lu asked whether he should immediately carry into practice what he heard.

passages.zh: 子曰：「有父兄在，如之何其聞斯行之？」
passages.en: The Master said, "There are your father and elder brothers to be consulted - why should you act on that principle of immediately carrying into practice what you hear?"

passages.zh: 冉有問：「聞斯行諸？」子曰：「聞斯行之。」
passages.en: Ran You asked the same, whether he should immediately carry into practice what he heard, and the Master answered, "Immediately carry into practice what you hear."

passages.zh: 公西華曰：「由也問聞斯行諸，子曰『有父兄在』；求也問聞斯行諸，子曰『聞斯行之』。赤也惑，敢問。」
passages.en: Gong Xi Hua said, "You asked whether he should carry immediately into practice what he heard, and you said, 'There are your father and elder brothers to be consulted.' Qiu asked whether he should immediately carry into practice what he heard, and you said, 'Carry it immediately into practice.' I, Chi, am perplexed, and venture to ask you for an explanation."

passages.zh: 子曰：「求也退，故進之；由也兼人，故退之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Qiu is retiring and slow; therefore I urged him forward. You has more than his own share of energy; therefore I kept him back."

passages.zh: 子畏於匡，顏淵後。
passages.en: The Master was put in fear in Kuang and Yan Yuan fell behind.

passages.zh: 子曰：「吾以女為死矣。」
passages.en: The Master, on his rejoining him, said, "I thought you had died."

passages.zh: 曰：「子在，回何敢死？」
passages.en: Hui replied, "While you were alive, how should I presume to die?"

passages.zh: 季子然問：「仲由、冉求可謂大臣與？」
passages.en: Ji Zi Ran asked whether Zhong You and Ran Qiu could be called great ministers.

passages.zh: 子曰：「吾以子為異之問，曾由與求之問。
passages.en: The Master said, "I thought you would ask about some extraordinary individuals, and you only ask about You and Qiu!

passages.zh: 所謂大臣者：以道事君，不可則止。
passages.en: What is called a great minister, is one who serves his prince according to what is right, and when he finds he cannot do so, retires.

passages.zh: 今由與求也，可謂具臣矣。」
passages.en: Now, as to You and Qiu, they may be called ordinary ministers."

passages.zh: 曰：「然則從之者與？」
passages.en: Zi Ran said, "Then they will always follow their chief - will they?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「弒父與君，亦不從也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "In an act of parricide or regicide, they would not follow him."

passages.zh: 子路使子羔為費宰。
passages.en: Zi Lu got Zi Gao appointed governor of Fei.

passages.zh: 子曰：「賊夫人之子。」
passages.en: The Master said, "You are injuring a man's son."

passages.zh: 子路曰：「有民人焉，有社稷焉。何必讀書，然後為學？」
passages.en: Zi Lu said, "There are (there) common people and officers; there are the altars of the spirits of the land and grain. Why must one read books before he can be considered to have learned?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「是故惡夫佞者。」
passages.en: The Master said, "It is on this account that I hate your glib-tongued people."

passages.zh: 子路、曾皙、冉有、公西華侍坐。
passages.en: Zi Lu, Zeng Xi, Ran You, and Gong Xi Hua were sitting by the Master.

passages.zh: 子曰：「以吾一日長乎爾，毋吾以也。
passages.en: He said to them, "Though I am a day or so older than you, do not think of that.

passages.zh: 居則曰：「不吾知也！』如或知爾，則何以哉？」
passages.en: From day to day you are saying, 'We are not known.' If some ruler were to know you, what would you like to do?"

passages.zh: 子路率爾而對曰：「千乘之國，攝乎大國之間，加之以師旅，因之以饑饉；
passages.en: Zi Lu hastily and lightly replied, "Suppose the case of a state of ten thousand chariots; let it be straitened between other large states; let it be suffering from invading armies; and to this let there be added a famine in corn and in all vegetables -

passages.zh: 由也為之，比及三年，可使有勇，且知方也。」
passages.en: if I were intrusted with the government of it, in three years' time I could make the people to be bold, and to recognize the rules of righteous conduct."

passages.zh: 夫子哂之。
passages.en: The Master smiled at him.

passages.zh: 「求！爾何如？」
passages.en: Turning to Ran You, he said, "Qiu, what are your wishes?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「方六七十，如五六十，求也為之，比及三年，可使足民。
passages.en: Qiu replied, "Suppose a state of sixty or seventy li square, or one of fifty or sixty, and let me have the government of it - in three years' time, I could make plenty to abound among the people.

passages.zh: 如其禮樂，以俟君子。」
passages.en: As to teaching them the principles of propriety, and music, I must wait for the rise of a superior man to do that."

passages.zh: 「赤！爾何如？」
passages.en: "What are your wishes, Chi," said the Master next to Gong Xi Hua.

passages.zh: 對曰：「非曰能之，願學焉。宗廟之事，如會同，端章甫，願為小相焉。」
passages.en: Chi replied, "I do not say that my ability extends to these things, but I should wish to learn them. At the services of the ancestral temple, and at the audiences of the princes with the sovereign, I should like, dressed in the dark square-made robe and the black linen cap, to act as a small assistant."

passages.zh: 「點！爾何如？」
passages.en: Last of all, the Master asked Zeng Xi, "Dian, what are your wishes?"

passages.zh: 鼓瑟希，鏗爾，舍瑟而作。
passages.en: Dian, pausing as he was playing on his lute, while it was yet twanging, laid the instrument aside, and rose.

passages.zh: 對曰：「異乎三子者之撰。」
passages.en: He said, "My wishes are different from the cherished purposes of these three gentlemen."

passages.zh: 子曰：「何傷乎？亦各言其志也。」
passages.en: Said the Master, "What harm is there in that? Do you also, as well as they, speak out your wishes."

passages.zh: 曰：「莫春者，春服既成。冠者五六人，童子六七人，浴乎沂，風乎舞雩，詠而歸。」
passages.en: Dian then said, "In this, the last month of spring, with the dress of the season all complete, along with five or six young men who have assumed the cap, and six or seven boys, I would wash in the Yi, enjoy the breeze among the rain altars, and return home singing."

passages.zh: 夫子喟然歎曰：「吾與點也！」
passages.en: The Master heaved a sigh and said, "I give my approval to Dian."

passages.zh: 三子者出，曾皙後。
passages.en: The three others having gone out, Zeng Xi remained behind,

passages.zh: 曾皙曰：「夫三子者之言何如？」
passages.en: and said, "What do you think of the words of these three friends?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「亦各言其志也已矣。」
passages.en: The Master replied, "They simply told each one his wishes."

passages.zh: 曰：「夫子何哂由也？」
passages.en: Xi pursued, "Master, why did you smile at You?"

passages.zh: 曰：「為國以禮，其言不讓，是故哂之。」
passages.en: He was answered, "The management of a state demands the rules of propriety. His words were not humble; therefore I smiled at him."

passages.zh: 「唯求則非邦也與？」
passages.en: Xi again said, "But was it not a state which Qiu proposed for himself?"

passages.zh: 「安見方六七十如五六十而非邦也者？」
passages.en: The reply was, "Yes; did you ever see a territory of sixty or seventy li or one of fifty or sixty, which was not a state?"

passages.zh: 「唯赤則非邦也與？」
passages.en: Once more, Xi inquired, "And was it not a state which Chi proposed for himself?"

passages.zh: 「宗廟會同，非諸侯而何？赤也為之小，孰能為之大？」
passages.en: The Master again replied, "Yes; who but princes have to do with ancestral temples, and with audiences but the sovereign? If Chi were to be a small assistant in these services, who could be a great one?"

passages.zh: 顏淵問仁。
passages.en: Yan Yuan asked about perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 子曰：「克己復禮為仁。
passages.en: The Master said, "To subdue one's self and return to propriety, is perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 一日克己復禮，天下歸仁焉。
passages.en: If a man can for one day subdue himself and return to propriety, all under heaven will ascribe perfect virtue to him.

passages.zh: 為仁由己，而由人乎哉？」
passages.en: Is the practice of perfect virtue from a man himself, or is it from others?"

passages.zh: 顏淵曰：「請問其目。」
passages.en: Yan Yuan said, "I beg to ask the steps of that process."

passages.zh: 子曰：「非禮勿視，非禮勿聽，非禮勿言，非禮勿動。」
passages.en: The Master replied, "Look not at what is contrary to propriety; listen not to what is contrary to propriety; speak not what is contrary to propriety; make no movement which is contrary to propriety."

passages.zh: 顏淵曰：「回雖不敏，請事斯語矣。」
passages.en: Yan Yuan then said, "Though I am deficient in intelligence and vigor, I will make it my business to practice this lesson."

passages.zh: 仲弓問仁。
passages.en: Zhong Gong asked about perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 子曰：「出門如見大賓，使民如承大祭。
passages.en: The Master said, "It is, when you go abroad, to behave to every one as if you were receiving a great guest; to employ the people as if you were assisting at a great sacrifice;

passages.zh: 己所不欲，勿施於人。
passages.en: not to do to others as you would not wish done to yourself;

passages.zh: 在邦無怨，在家無怨。」
passages.en: to have no murmuring against you in the country, and none in the family."

passages.zh: 仲弓曰：「雍雖不敏，請事斯語矣。」
passages.en: Zhong Gong said, "Though I am deficient in intelligence and vigor, I will make it my business to practice this lesson."

passages.zh: 司馬牛問仁。
passages.en: Si Ma Niu asked about perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 子曰：「仁者其言也訒。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The man of perfect virtue is cautious and slow in his speech."

passages.zh: 曰：「其言也訒，斯謂之仁已乎？」
passages.en: Niu replied, "Cautious and slow in his speech! Is this what is meant by perfect virtue?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「為之難，言之得無訒乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "When a man feels the difficulty of doing, can he be other than cautious and slow in speaking?"

passages.zh: 司馬牛問君子。
passages.en: Si Ma Niu asked about the superior man.

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子不憂不懼。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man has neither anxiety nor fear."

passages.zh: 曰：「不憂不懼，斯謂之君子已乎？」
passages.en: Niu said, "Being without anxiety or fear! Does this constitute what we call the superior man?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「內省不疚，夫何憂何懼？」
passages.en: The Master said, "When internal examination discovers nothing wrong, what is there to be anxious about, what is there to fear?"

passages.zh: 司馬牛憂曰：「人皆有兄弟，我獨亡。」
passages.en: Si Ma Niu, full of anxiety, said, "Other men all have their brothers, I only have not."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「商聞之矣：死生有命，富貴在天。
passages.en: Zi Xia said to him, "There is the following saying which I have heard - 'Death and life have their determined appointment; riches and honors depend upon Heaven.'

passages.zh: 君子敬而無失，與人恭而有禮。
passages.en: Let the superior man never fail reverentially to order his own conduct, and let him be respectful to others and observant of propriety -

passages.zh: 四海之內，皆兄弟也。君子何患乎無兄弟也？」
passages.en: then all within the four seas will be his brothers. What has the superior man to do with being distressed because he has no brothers?"

passages.zh: 子張問明。
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked what constituted intelligence.

passages.zh: 子曰：「浸潤之譖，膚受之愬，不行焉。可謂明也已矣。
passages.en: The Master said, "He with whom neither slander that gradually soaks into the mind, nor statements that startle like a wound in the flesh, are successful, may be called intelligent indeed.

passages.zh: 浸潤之譖膚受之愬不行焉，可謂遠也已矣。」
passages.en: Yea, he with whom neither soaking slander, nor startling statements, are successful, may be called farseeing."

passages.zh: 子貢問政。
passages.en: Zi Gong asked about government.

passages.zh: 子曰：「足食。足兵。民信之矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The requisites of government are that there be sufficiency of food, sufficiency of military equipment, and the confidence of the people in their ruler."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「必不得已而去，於斯三者何先？」曰：「去兵。」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "If it cannot be helped, and one of these must be dispensed with, which of the three should be foregone first?" "The military equipment," said the Master.

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「必不得已而去，於斯二者何先？」
passages.en: Zi Gong again asked, "If it cannot be helped, and one of the remaining two must be dispensed with, which of them should be foregone?"

passages.zh: 曰：「去食。自古皆有死，民無信不立。」
passages.en: The Master answered, "Part with the food. From of old, death has been the lot of all men; but if the people have no faith in their rulers, there is no standing for the state."

passages.zh: 棘子成曰：「君子質而已矣，何以文為？」
passages.en: Ji Zi Cheng said, "In a superior man it is only the substantial qualities which are wanted; why should we seek for ornamental accomplishments?"

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「惜乎！夫子之說，君子也。駟不及舌。
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "Alas! Your words, sir, show you to be a superior man, but four horses cannot overtake the tongue.

passages.zh: 文猶質也，質猶文也。虎豹之鞟，猶犬羊之鞟。」
passages.en: Ornament is as substance; substance is as ornament. The hide of a tiger or a leopard stripped of its hair, is like the hide of a dog or a goat stripped of its hair."

passages.zh: 哀公問於有若曰：「年饑，用不足，如之何？」
passages.en: The duke Ai inquired of You Ruo, saying, "The year is one of scarcity, and the returns for expenditure are not sufficient - what is to be done?"

passages.zh: 有若對曰：「盍徹乎？」
passages.en: You Ruo replied to him, "Why not simply tithe the people?"

passages.zh: 曰：「二，吾猶不足，如之何其徹也？」
passages.en: The duke replied, "With two tenths I find it not enough - how could I do with that system of one tenth?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「百姓足，君孰與不足？百姓不足，君孰與足？」
passages.en: You Ruo answered, "If the people have plenty, their prince will not be left to want alone. If the people are in want, their prince cannot enjoy plenty alone."

passages.zh: 子張問崇德、辨惑。
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked how virtue was to be exalted, and delusions to be discovered.

passages.zh: 子曰：「主忠信，徙義，崇德也。
passages.en: The Master said, "Hold faithfulness and sincerity as first principles, and be moving continually to what is right - this is the way to exalt one's virtue.

passages.zh: 愛之欲其生，惡之欲其死。既欲其生，又欲其死，是惑也。
passages.en: You love a man and wish him to live; you hate him and wish him to die. Having wished him to live, you also wish him to die. This is a case of delusion.

passages.zh: 『誠不以富，亦祗以異。』」
passages.en: 'It may not be on account of her being rich, yet you come to make a difference.'"

passages.zh: 齊景公問政於孔子。
passages.en: The duke Jing, of Qi, asked Confucius about government.

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「君君，臣臣，父父，子子。」
passages.en: Confucius replied, "There is government, when the prince is prince, and the minister is minister; when the father is father, and the son is son."

passages.zh: 公曰：「善哉！信如君不君，臣不臣，父不父，子不子，雖有粟，吾得而食諸？」
passages.en: "Good!" said the duke; "if, indeed, the prince be not prince, the minister not minister, the father not father, and the son not son, although I have my revenue, can I enjoy it?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「片言可以折獄者，其由也與？」
passages.en: The Master said, "Ah! it is You, who could with half a word settle litigations!"

passages.zh: 子路無宿諾。
passages.en: Zi Lu never slept over a promise.

passages.zh: 子曰：「聽訟，吾猶人也，必也使無訟乎！」
passages.en: The Master said, "In hearing litigations, I am like any other body. What is necessary, however, is to cause the people to have no litigations."

passages.zh: 子張問政。
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked about government.

passages.zh: 子曰：「居之無倦，行之以忠。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The art of governing is to keep its affairs before the mind without weariness, and to practice them with undeviating consistency."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子博學於文，約之以禮，亦可以弗畔矣夫！」
passages.en: The Master said, "By extensively studying all learning, and keeping himself under the restraint of the rules of propriety, one may thus likewise not err from what is right."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子成人之美，不成人之惡。小人反是。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man seeks to perfect the admirable qualities of men, and does not seek to perfect their bad qualities. The mean man does the opposite of this."

passages.zh: 季康子問政於孔子。
passages.en: Ji Kang asked Confucius about government.

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「政者，正也。子帥以正，孰敢不正？」
passages.en: Confucius replied, "To govern means to rectify. If you lead on the people with correctness, who will dare not to be correct?"

passages.zh: 季康子患盜，問於孔子。
passages.en: Ji Kang, distressed about the number of thieves in the state, inquired of Confucius how to do away with them.

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「苟子之不欲，雖賞之不竊。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "If you, sir, were not covetous, although you should reward them to do it, they would not steal."

passages.zh: 季康子問政於孔子曰：「如殺無道，以就有道，何如？」
passages.en: Ji Kang asked Confucius about government, saying, "What do you say to killing the unprincipled for the good of the principled?"

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「子為政，焉用殺？
passages.en: Confucius replied, "Sir, in carrying on your government, why should you use killing at all?

passages.zh: 子欲善，而民善矣。
passages.en: Let your evinced desires be for what is good, and the people will be good.

passages.zh: 君子之德風，小人之德草。草上之風，必偃。」
passages.en: The relation between superiors and inferiors is like that between the wind and the grass. The grass must bend, when the wind blows across it."

passages.zh: 子張問：「士何如斯可謂之達矣？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked, "What must the officer be, who may be said to be distinguished?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「何哉，爾所謂達者？」
passages.en: The Master said, "What is it you call being distinguished?"

passages.zh: 子張對曰：「在邦必聞，在家必聞。」
passages.en: Zi Zhang replied, "It is to be heard of through the state, to be heard of throughout his clan."

passages.zh: 子曰：「是聞也，非達也。
passages.en: The Master said, "That is notoriety, not distinction.

passages.zh: 夫達也者，質直而好義，察言而觀色，慮以下人。在邦必達，在家必達。
passages.en: Now the man of distinction is solid and straightforward, and loves righteousness. He examines people's words, and looks at their countenances. He is anxious to humble himself to others. Such a man will be distinguished in the country; he will be distinguished in his clan.

passages.zh: 夫聞也者，色取仁而行違，居之不疑。在邦必聞，在家必聞。」
passages.en: As to the man of notoriety, he assumes the appearance of virtue, but his actions are opposed to it, and he rests in this character without any doubts about himself. Such a man will be heard of in the country; he will be heard of in the clan."

passages.zh: 樊遲從遊於舞雩之下，曰：「敢問崇德、脩慝、辨惑。」
passages.en: Fan Chi rambling with the Master under the trees about the rain altars, said, "I venture to ask how to exalt virtue, to correct cherished evil, and to discover delusions."

passages.zh: 子曰：「善哉問！
passages.en: The Master said, "Truly a good question!

passages.zh: 先事後得，非崇德與？
passages.en: If doing what is to be done be made the first business, and success a secondary consideration - is not this the way to exalt virtue?

passages.zh: 攻其惡，無攻人之惡，非脩慝與？
passages.en: To assail one's own wickedness and not assail that of others - is not this the way to correct cherished evil?

passages.zh: 一朝之忿，忘其身，以及其親，非惑與？」
passages.en: For a morning's anger to disregard one's own life, and involve that of his parents - is not this a case of delusion?"

passages.zh: 樊遲問仁。子曰：「愛人。」
passages.en: Fan Chi asked about benevolence. The Master said, "It is to love all men."

passages.zh: 問知。子曰：「知人。」
passages.en: He asked about knowledge. The Master said, "It is to know all men."

passages.zh: 樊遲未達。
passages.en: Fan Chi did not immediately understand these answers.

passages.zh: 子曰：「舉直錯諸枉，能使枉者直。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Employ the upright and put aside all the crooked; in this way the crooked can be made to be upright."

passages.zh: 樊遲退，見子夏。
passages.en: Fan Chi retired, and, seeing Zi Xia, he said to him,

passages.zh: 曰：「鄉也吾見於夫子而問知，子曰，『舉直錯諸枉，能使枉者直』，何謂也？」
passages.en: "A little while ago, I had an interview with our Master, and asked him about knowledge. He said, 'Employ the upright, and put aside all the crooked; in this way, the crooked will be made to be upright.' What did he mean?"

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「富哉言乎！舜有天下，選於眾，舉皋陶，不仁者遠矣。湯有天下，選於眾，舉伊尹，不仁者遠矣。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "Truly rich is his saying! Shun, being in possession of the kingdom, selected from among all the people, and employed Gao Yao, on which all who were devoid of virtue disappeared. Tang, being in possession of the kingdom, selected from among all the people, and employed Yi Yin, and all who were devoid of virtue disappeared."

passages.zh: 子貢問友。
passages.en: Zi Gong asked about friendship.

passages.zh: 子曰：「忠告而善道之，不可則止，無自辱焉。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Faithfully admonish your friend, and skillfully lead him on. If you find him impracticable, stop. Do not disgrace yourself."

passages.zh: 曾子曰：「君子以文會友，以友輔仁。」
passages.en: The philosopher Zeng said, "The superior man on grounds of culture meets with his friends, and by friendship helps his virtue."

passages.zh: 子路問政。
passages.en: Zi Lu asked about government.

passages.zh: 子曰：「先之，勞之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Go before the people with your example, and be laborious in their affairs."

passages.zh: 請益。曰：「無倦。」
passages.en: He requested further instruction, and was answered, "Be not weary (in these things)."

passages.zh: 仲弓為季氏宰，問政。
passages.en: Zhong Gong, being chief minister to the head of the Ji family, asked about government.

passages.zh: 子曰：「先有司，赦小過，舉賢才。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Employ first the services of your various officers, pardon small faults, and raise to office men of virtue and talents."

passages.zh: 曰：「焉知賢才而舉之？」
passages.en: Zhong Gong said, "How shall I know the men of virtue and talent, so that I may raise them to office?"

passages.zh: 曰：「舉爾所知。爾所不知，人其舍諸？」
passages.en: He was answered, "Raise to office those whom you know. As to those whom you do not know, will others neglect them?"

passages.zh: 子路曰：「衛君待子而為政，子將奚先？」
passages.en: Zi Lu said, "The ruler of Wei has been waiting for you, in order with you to administer the government. What will you consider the first thing to be done?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「必也正名乎！」
passages.en: The Master replied, "What is necessary is to rectify names."

passages.zh: 子路曰：「有是哉，子之迂也！奚其正？」
passages.en: "So! indeed!" said Zi Lu. "You are wide of the mark! Why must there be such rectification?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「野哉由也！君子於其所不知，蓋闕如也。
passages.en: The Master said, "How uncultivated you are, You! A superior man, in regard to what he does not know, shows a cautious reserve.

passages.zh: 名不正，則言不順；
passages.en: If names be not correct, language is not in accordance with the truth of things.

passages.zh: 言不順，則事不成；
passages.en: If language be not in accordance with the truth of things, affairs cannot be carried on to success.

passages.zh: 事不成，則禮樂不興；
passages.en: When affairs cannot be carried on to success, proprieties and music will not flourish.

passages.zh: 禮樂不興，則刑罰不中；
passages.en: When proprieties and music do not flourish, punishments will not be properly awarded.

passages.zh: 刑罰不中，則民無所措手足。
passages.en: When punishments are not properly awarded, the people do not know how to move hand or foot.

passages.zh: 故君子名之必可言也，言之必可行也。
passages.en: Therefore a superior man considers it necessary that the names he uses may be spoken appropriately, and also that what he speaks may be carried out appropriately.

passages.zh: 君子於其言，無所苟而已矣。」
passages.en: What the superior man requires is just that in his words there may be nothing incorrect."

passages.zh: 樊遲請學稼，子曰：「吾不如老農。」
passages.en: Fan Chi requested to be taught husbandry. The Master said, "I am not so good for that as an old husbandman."

passages.zh: 請學為圃。曰：「吾不如老圃。」
passages.en: He requested also to be taught gardening, and was answered, "I am not so good for that as an old gardener."

passages.zh: 樊遲出。
passages.en: Fan Chi having gone out,

passages.zh: 子曰：「小人哉，樊須也！
passages.en: the Master said, "A small man, indeed, is Fan Xu!

passages.zh: 上好禮，則民莫敢不敬；
passages.en: If a superior man love propriety, the people will not dare not to be reverent.

passages.zh: 上好義，則民莫敢不服；
passages.en: If he love righteousness, the people will not dare not to submit to his example.

passages.zh: 上好信，則民莫敢不用情。
passages.en: If he love good faith, the people will not dare not to be sincere.

passages.zh: 夫如是，則四方之民襁負其子而至矣，焉用稼？」
passages.en: Now, when these things obtain, the people from all quarters will come to him, bearing their children on their backs - what need has he of a knowledge of husbandry?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「誦詩三百，授之以政，不達；
passages.en: The Master said, "Though a man may be able to recite the three hundred odes, yet if, when intrusted with a governmental charge, he knows not how to act,

passages.zh: 使於四方，不能專對；
passages.en: or if, when sent to any quarter on a mission, he cannot give his replies unassisted,

passages.zh: 雖多，亦奚以為？」
passages.en: notwithstanding the extent of his learning, of what practical use is it?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「其身正，不令而行；
passages.en: The Master said, "When a prince's personal conduct is correct, his government is effective without the issuing of orders.

passages.zh: 其身不正，雖令不從。」
passages.en: If his personal conduct is not correct, he may issue orders, but they will not be followed."

passages.zh: 子曰：「魯衛之政，兄弟也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The governments of Lu and Wei are brothers."

passages.zh: 子謂衛公子荊，「善居室。
passages.en: The Master said of Jing, a scion of the ducal family of Wei, that he knew the economy of a family well.

passages.zh: 始有，曰：『苟合矣。』
passages.en: When he began to have means, he said, "Ha! here is a collection!"

passages.zh: 少有，曰：『苟完矣。』
passages.en: When they were a little increased, he said, "Ha! this is complete!"

passages.zh: 富有，曰：『苟美矣。』」
passages.en: When he had become rich, he said, "Ha! this is admirable!"

passages.zh: 子適衛，冉有僕。
passages.en: When the Master went to Wei, Ran You acted as driver of his carriage.

passages.zh: 子曰：「庶矣哉！」
passages.en: The Master observed, "How numerous are the people!"

passages.zh: 冉有曰：「既庶矣。又何加焉？」曰：「富之。」
passages.en: You said, "Since they are thus numerous, what more shall be done for them?" "Enrich them," was the reply.

passages.zh: 曰：「既富矣，又何加焉？」子曰：「教之。」
passages.en: "And when they have been enriched, what more shall be done?" The Master said, "Teach them."

passages.zh: 子曰：「苟有用我者。期月而已可也，三年有成。」
passages.en: The Master said, "If there were (any of the princes) who would employ me, in the course of twelve months, I should have done something considerable. In three years, the government would be perfected."

passages.zh: 子曰：「善人為邦百年，亦可以勝殘去殺矣。誠哉是言也！」
passages.en: The Master said, "'If good men were to govern a country in succession for a hundred years, they would be able to transform the violently bad, and dispense with capital punishments.' True indeed is this saying!"

passages.zh: 子曰：「如有王者，必世而後仁。」
passages.en: The Master said, "If a truly royal ruler were to arise, it would still require a generation, and then virtue would prevail."

passages.zh: 子曰：「苟正其身矣，於從政乎何有？
passages.en: The Master said, "If a minister make his own conduct correct, what difficulty will he have in assisting in government?

passages.zh: 不能正其身，如正人何？」
passages.en: If he cannot rectify himself, what has he to do with rectifying others?"

passages.zh: 冉子退朝。子曰：「何晏也？」
passages.en: The disciple Ran returning from the court, the Master said to him, "How are you so late?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「有政。」
passages.en: He replied, "We had government business."

passages.zh: 子曰：「其事也。如有政，雖不吾以，吾其與聞之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "It must have been family affairs. If there had been government business, though I am not now in office, I should have been consulted about it."

passages.zh: 定公問：「一言而可以興邦，有諸？」
passages.en: The Duke Ding asked whether there was a single sentence which could make a country prosperous.

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「言不可以若是其幾也。
passages.en: Confucius replied, "Such an effect cannot be expected from one sentence.

passages.zh: 人之言曰：『為君難，為臣不易。』
passages.en: There is a saying, however, which people have - 'To be a prince is difficult; to be a minister is not easy.'

passages.zh: 如知為君之難也，不幾乎一言而興邦乎？」
passages.en: If a ruler knows this - the difficulty of being a prince - may there not be expected from this one sentence the prosperity of his country?"

passages.zh: 曰：「一言而喪邦，有諸？」
passages.en: The duke then said, "Is there a single sentence which can ruin a country?"

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「言不可以若是其幾也。
passages.en: Confucius replied, "Such an effect as that cannot be expected from one sentence.

passages.zh: 人之言曰：『予無樂乎為君，唯其言而莫予違也。』
passages.en: There is, however, the saying which people have - 'I have no pleasure in being a prince, but only in that no one can offer any opposition to what I say!'

passages.zh: 如其善而莫之違也，不亦善乎？
passages.en: If a ruler's words be good, is it not also good that no one oppose them?

passages.zh: 如不善而莫之違也，不幾乎一言而喪邦乎？」
passages.en: But if they are not good, and no one opposes them, may there not be expected from this one sentence the ruin of his country?"

passages.zh: 葉公問政。
passages.en: The duke of She asked about government.

passages.zh: 子曰：「近者說，遠者來。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Good government obtains, when those who are near are made happy, and those who are far off are attracted."

passages.zh: 子夏為莒父宰，問政。
passages.en: Zi Xia, being governor of Ju Fu, asked about government.

passages.zh: 子曰：「無欲速，無見小利。
passages.en: The Master said, "Do not be desirous to have things done quickly; do not look at small advantages.

passages.zh: 欲速，則不達；見小利，則大事不成。」
passages.en: Desire to have things done quickly prevents their being done thoroughly. Looking at small advantages prevents great affairs from being accomplished."

passages.zh: 葉公語孔子曰：「吾黨有直躬者，其父攘羊，而子證之。」
passages.en: The Duke of She informed Confucius, saying, "Among us here there are those who may be styled upright in their conduct. If their father have stolen a sheep, they will bear witness to the fact."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「吾黨之直者異於是。父為子隱，子為父隱，直在其中矣。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "Among us, in our part of the country, those who are upright are different from this. The father conceals the misconduct of the son, and the son conceals the misconduct of the father. Uprightness is to be found in this."

passages.zh: 樊遲問仁。
passages.en: Fan Chi asked about perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 子曰：「居處恭，執事敬，與人忠。雖之夷狄，不可棄也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "It is, in retirement, to be sedately grave; in the management of business, to be reverently attentive; in intercourse with others, to be strictly sincere. Though a man go among rude, uncultivated tribes, these qualities may not be neglected."

passages.zh: 子貢問曰：「何如斯可謂之士矣？」
passages.en: Zi Gong asked, saying, "What qualities must a man possess to entitle him to be called an officer?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「行己有恥，使於四方，不辱君命，可謂士矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He who in his conduct of himself maintains a sense of shame, and when sent to any quarter will not disgrace his prince's commission, deserves to be called an officer."

passages.zh: 曰：「敢問其次。」
passages.en: Zi Gong pursued, "I venture to ask who may be placed in the next lower rank?"

passages.zh: 曰：「宗族稱孝焉，鄉黨稱弟焉。」
passages.en: And he was told, "He whom the circle of his relatives pronounce to be filial, whom his fellow villagers and neighbors pronounce to be fraternal."

passages.zh: 曰：「敢問其次。」
passages.en: Again the disciple asked, "I venture to ask about the class still next in order."

passages.zh: 曰：「言必信，行必果，硜硜然小人哉！抑亦可以為次矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "They are determined to be sincere in what they say, and to carry out what they do. They are obstinate little men. Yet perhaps they may make the next class."

passages.zh: 曰：「今之從政者何如？」
passages.en: Zi Gong finally inquired, "Of what sort are those of the present day, who engage in government?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「噫！斗筲之人，何足算也。」
passages.en: The Master said "Pooh! they are so many pecks and hampers, not worth being taken into account."

passages.zh: 子曰：「不得中行而與之，必也狂狷乎！
passages.en: The Master said, "Since I cannot get men pursuing the due medium, to whom I might communicate my instructions, I must find the ardent and the cautiously-decided.

passages.zh: 狂者進取，狷者有所不為也。」
passages.en: The ardent will advance and lay hold of truth; the cautiously-decided will keep themselves from what is wrong."

passages.zh: 子曰：「南人有言曰：『人而無恆，不可以作巫醫。』善夫！」
passages.en: The Master said, "The people of the south have a saying - 'A man without constancy cannot be either a wizard or a doctor.' Good!

passages.zh: 「不恆其德，或承之羞。」
passages.en: Inconstant in his virtue, he will be visited with disgrace."

passages.zh: 子曰：「不占而已矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "This arises simply from not attending to the prognostication."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子和而不同，小人同而不和。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man is affable, but not adulatory; the mean man is adulatory, but not affable."

passages.zh: 子貢問曰：「鄉人皆好之，何如？」
passages.en: Zi Gong asked, saying, "What do you say of a man who is loved by all the people of his neighborhood?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「未可也。」
passages.en: The Master replied, "We may not for that accord our approval of him."

passages.zh: 「鄉人皆惡之，何如？」
passages.en: "And what do you say of him who is hated by all the people of his neighborhood?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「未可也。不如鄉人之善者好之，其不善者惡之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "We may not for that conclude that he is bad. It is better than either of these cases that the good in the neighborhood love him, and the bad hate him."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子易事而難說也：說之不以道，不說也；
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man is easy to serve and difficult to please. If you try to please him in any way which is not accordant with right, he will not be pleased.

passages.zh: 及其使人也，器之。
passages.en: But in his employment of men, he uses them according to their capacity.

passages.zh: 小人難事而易說也：說之雖不以道，說也；
passages.en: The mean man is difficult to serve, and easy to please. If you try to please him, though it be in a way which is not accordant with right, he may be pleased.

passages.zh: 及其使人也，求備焉。」
passages.en: But in his employment of men, he wishes them to be equal to everything."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子泰而不驕，小人驕而不泰。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man has a dignified ease without pride. The mean man has pride without a dignified ease."

passages.zh: 子曰：「剛毅、木訥，近仁。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The firm, the enduring, the simple, and the modest are near to virtue."

passages.zh: 子路問曰：「何如斯可謂之士矣？」
passages.en: Zi Lu asked, saying, "What qualities must a man possess to entitle him to be called a scholar?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「切切、偲偲、怡怡如也，可謂士矣。
passages.en: The Master said, "He must be thus: earnest, urgent, and bland - among his friends, earnest and urgent; among his brethren, bland."

passages.zh: 朋友切切、偲偲，兄弟怡怡。」
passages.en: Among his friends, earnest and urgent; among his brethren, bland.

passages.zh: 子曰：「善人教民七年，亦可以即戎矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Let a good man teach the people seven years, and they may then likewise be employed in war."

passages.zh: 子曰：「以不教民戰，是謂棄之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "To lead an uninstructed people to war, is to throw them away."

passages.zh: 憲問恥。
passages.en: Xian asked what was shameful.

passages.zh: 子曰：「邦有道，穀；邦無道，穀，恥也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "When good government prevails in a state, to be thinking only of salary; and, when bad government prevails, to be thinking, in the same way, only of salary - this is shameful."

passages.zh: 「克、伐、怨、欲不行焉，可以為仁矣？」
passages.en: "When the love of superiority, boasting, resentments, and covetousness are repressed, this may be deemed perfect virtue."

passages.zh: 子曰：「可以為難矣，仁則吾不知也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "This may be regarded as the achievement of what is difficult. But I do not know that it is to be deemed perfect virtue."

passages.zh: 子曰：「士而懷居，不足以為士矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The scholar who cherishes the love of comfort is not fit to be deemed a scholar."

passages.zh: 子曰：「邦有道，危言危行；
passages.en: The Master said, "When good government prevails in a state, language may be lofty and bold, and actions the same.

passages.zh: 邦無道，危行言孫。」
passages.en: When bad government prevails, the actions may be lofty and bold, but the language may be with some reserve."

passages.zh: 子曰：「有德者，必有言。有言者，不必有德。
passages.en: The Master said, "The virtuous will be sure to speak correctly, but those whose speech is good may not always be virtuous.

passages.zh: 仁者，必有勇。勇者，不必有仁。」
passages.en: Men of principle are sure to be bold, but those who are bold may not always be men of principle."

passages.zh: 南宮适問於孔子曰：「羿善射，奡盪舟，俱不得其死然；
passages.en: Nan Gong Kuo, submitting an inquiry to Confucius, said, "Yi was skillful at archery, and Ao could move a boat along upon the land, but neither of them died a natural death.

passages.zh: 禹稷躬稼，而有天下。」
passages.en: Yu and Ji personally wrought at the toils of husbandry, and they became possessors of the kingdom."

passages.zh: 夫子不答，南宮适出。
passages.en: The Master made no reply; but when Nan Gong Kuo went out,

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子哉若人！尚德哉若人！」
passages.en: he said, "A superior man indeed is this! An esteemer of virtue indeed is this!"

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子而不仁者有矣夫，未有小人而仁者也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Superior men, and yet not always virtuous, there have been, alas! But there never has been a mean man, and, at the same time, virtuous."

passages.zh: 子曰：「愛之，能勿勞乎？忠焉，能勿誨乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "Can there be love which does not lead to strictness with its object? Can there be loyalty which does not lead to the instruction of its object?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「為命：裨諶草創之，世叔討論之，行人子羽脩飾之，東里子產潤色之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "In preparing the governmental notifications, Pi Shen first made the rough draft; Shi Shu examined and discussed its contents; Zi Yu, the manager of foreign intercourse, then polished the style; and, finally, Zi Chan of Dong Li gave it the proper elegance and finish."

passages.zh: 或問子產。子曰：「惠人也。」
passages.en: Some one asked about Zi Chan. The Master said, "He was a kind man."

passages.zh: 問子西。曰：「彼哉！彼哉！」
passages.en: He asked about Zi Xi. The Master said, "That man! That man!"

passages.zh: 問管仲。曰：「人也。奪伯氏駢邑三百，飯疏食，沒齒，無怨言。」
passages.en: He asked about Guan Zhong. "For him," said the Master, "the city of Pian, with three hundred families, was taken from the chief of the Bo family, who though to the end of his life he had only coarse rice to eat did not utter a murmuring word."

passages.zh: 子曰：「貧而無怨難，富而無驕易。」
passages.en: The Master said, "To be poor without murmuring is difficult. To be rich without being proud is easy."

passages.zh: 子曰：「孟公綽，為趙魏老則優，不可以為滕薛大夫。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Meng Gong Chuo is more than fit to be chief officer in the families of Zhao and Wei, but he is not fit to be great officer to either of the States Teng or Xue."

passages.zh: 子路問成人。
passages.en: Zi Lu asked what constituted a COMPLETE man.

passages.zh: 子曰：「若臧武仲之知，公綽之不欲，卞莊子之勇，冉求之藝，文之以禮樂，亦可以為成人矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Suppose a man with the knowledge of Zang Wu Zhong, the freedom from covetousness of Gong Chuo, the bravery of Zhuang of Bian, and the varied talents of Ran Qiu; add to these the accomplishments of the rules of propriety and music - such a one might be reckoned a COMPLETE man."

passages.zh: 曰：「今之成人者何必然？
passages.en: He then added, "But what is the necessity for a complete man of the present day to have all these things?

passages.zh: 見利思義，見危授命，久要不忘平生之言，亦可以為成人矣。」
passages.en: The man, who in the view of gain, thinks of righteousness; who in the view of danger is prepared to give up his life; and who does not forget an old agreement however far back it extends - such a man may be reckoned a COMPLETE man."

passages.zh: 子問公叔文子於公明賈曰：「信乎夫子不言、不笑、不取乎？」
passages.en: The Master asked Gong Ming Jia about Gong Ming Wen, saying, "Is it true that your master speaks not, laughs not, and takes not?"

passages.zh: 公明賈對曰：「以告者過也。
passages.en: Gong Ming Jia replied, "This has arisen from the reporters going beyond the truth.

passages.zh: 夫子時然後言，人不厭其言；
passages.en: My master speaks when it is the time to speak, and so men do not get tired of his speaking.

passages.zh: 樂然後笑，人不厭其笑；
passages.en: He laughs when there is occasion to be joyful, and so men do not get tired of his laughing.

passages.zh: 義然後取，人不厭其取。」
passages.en: He takes when it is consistent with righteousness to do so, and so men do not get tired of his taking."

passages.zh: 子曰：「其然，豈其然乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "So! But is it so with him?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「臧武仲以防求為後於魯，雖曰不要君，吾不信也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Zang Wu Zhong, keeping possession of Fang, asked of the duke of Lu to appoint a successor to him in his family. Although it may be said that he was not using force with his sovereign, I believe he was."

passages.zh: 子曰：「晉文公譎而不正，齊桓公正而不譎。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The duke Wen of Jin was crafty and not upright. The duke Huan of Qi was upright and not crafty."

passages.zh: 子路曰：「桓公殺公子糾，召忽死之，管仲不死。」曰：「未仁乎？」
passages.en: Zi Lu said, "The duke Huan caused his brother Jiu to be killed, when Shao Hu died with his master, but Guan Zhong did not die. May not I say that he was wanting in virtue?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「桓公九合諸侯，不以兵車，管仲之力也。如其仁！如其仁！」
passages.en: The Master said, "The Duke Huan assembled all the princes together, and that not with weapons of war and chariots - it was all through the influence of Guan Zhong. Whose beneficence was like his? Whose beneficence was like his?"

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「管仲非仁者與？桓公殺公子糾，不能死，又相之。」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "Guan Zhong, I apprehend, was wanting in virtue. When the Duke Huan caused his brother Jiu to be killed, Guan Zhong was not able to die with him. Moreover, he became prime minister to Huan."

passages.zh: 子曰：「管仲相桓公，霸諸侯，一匡天下，民到于今受其賜。
passages.en: The Master said, "Guan Zhong acted as prime minister to the duke Huan, made him leader of all the princes, and united and rectified the whole kingdom. Down to the present day, the people enjoy the gifts which he conferred.

passages.zh: 微管仲，吾其被髮左衽矣。
passages.en: But for Guan Zhong, we should now be wearing our hair unbound, and the lappets of our coats buttoning on the left side.

passages.zh: 豈若匹夫匹婦之為諒也，自經於溝瀆，而莫之知也。」
passages.en: Will you require from him the small fidelity of common men and common women, who would commit suicide in a stream or ditch, no one knowing anything about them?"

passages.zh: 公叔文子之臣大夫僎，與文子同升諸公。
passages.en: The great officer, Xian, who had been family minister to Gong Ming Wen, ascended to the prince's court in company with Wen.

passages.zh: 子聞之曰：「可以為文矣。」
passages.en: The Master, having heard of it, said, "He deserved to be considered WEN (the accomplished)."

passages.zh: 子言衛靈公之無道也，康子曰：「夫如是，奚而不喪？」
passages.en: The Master was speaking about the unprincipled course of the duke Ling of Wei, when Qi Kang said, "Since he is of such a character, how is it he does not lose his state?"

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「仲叔圉治賓客，祝鮀治宗廟，王孫賈治軍旅。夫如是，奚其喪？」
passages.en: Confucius said, "The Zhong Shu Yu has the superintendence of his guests and of strangers; the litanist, Tuo, has the management of his ancestral temple; and Wang Sun Jia has the direction of the army and forces - with such officers as these, how should he lose his state?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「其言之不怍，則為之也難。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He who speaks without modesty will find it difficult to make his words good."

passages.zh: 陳成子弒簡公。
passages.en: Chen Cheng murdered the duke Jian of Qi.

passages.zh: 孔子沐浴而朝，告於哀公曰：「陳恆弒其君，請討之。」
passages.en: Confucius bathed, went to court and informed the duke Ai, saying, "Chen Heng has slain his sovereign. I beg that you will undertake to punish him."

passages.zh: 公曰：「告夫三子！」
passages.en: The duke said, "Inform the chiefs of the three families of it."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「以吾從大夫之後，不敢不告也。君曰『告夫三子』者。」
passages.en: Confucius retired, and said, "Following in the rear of the great officers, I did not dare not to represent such a matter, and my prince says, 'Inform the chiefs of the three families of it.'"

passages.zh: 之三子告，不可。
passages.en: He went to the chiefs, and informed them, but they would not act.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「以吾從大夫之後，不敢不告也。」
passages.en: Confucius then said, "Following in the rear of the great officers, I did not dare not to represent such a matter."

passages.zh: 子路問事君。
passages.en: Zi Lu asked how a ruler should be served.

passages.zh: 子曰：「勿欺也，而犯之。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Do not impose on him, and, moreover, withstand him to his face."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子上達，小人下達。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The progress of the superior man is upwards; the progress of the mean man is downwards."

passages.zh: 子曰：「古之學者為己，今之學者為人。」
passages.en: The Master said, "In ancient times, men learned with a view to their own improvement. Nowadays, men learn with a view to the approbation of others."

passages.zh: 蘧伯玉使人於孔子。
passages.en: Qu Bo sent a messenger with friendly inquiries to Confucius.

passages.zh: 孔子與之坐而問焉，曰：「夫子何為？」
passages.en: Confucius sat with him, and questioned him. "What," said he! "is your master engaged in?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「夫子欲寡其過而未能也。」
passages.en: The messenger replied, "My master is anxious to make his faults few, but he has not yet succeeded."

passages.zh: 使者出。子曰：「使乎！使乎！」
passages.en: He then went out, and the Master said, "A messenger indeed! A messenger indeed!"

passages.zh: 子曰：「不在其位，不謀其政。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He who is not in any particular office has nothing to do with plans for the administration of its duties."

passages.zh: 曾子曰：「君子思不出其位。」
passages.en: The philosopher Zeng said, "The superior man, in his thoughts, does not go out of his place."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子恥其言而過其行。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man is modest in his speech, but exceeds in his actions."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子道者三，我無能焉：仁者不憂，知者不惑，勇者不懼。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The way of the superior man is threefold, but I am not equal to it. Virtuous, he is free from anxieties; wise, he is free from perplexities; bold, he is free from fear."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「夫子自道也。」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "Master, that is what you yourself say."

passages.zh: 子貢方人。
passages.en: Zi Gong was in the habit of comparing men together.

passages.zh: 子曰：「賜也賢乎哉？夫我則不暇。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Ci must have reached a high pitch of excellence! Now, I have not leisure for this."

passages.zh: 子曰：「不患人之不己知，患其不能也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "I will not be concerned at men's not knowing me; I will be concerned at my own want of ability."

passages.zh: 子曰：「不逆詐，不億不信。抑亦先覺者，是賢乎！」
passages.en: The Master said, "He who does not anticipate attempts to deceive him, nor think beforehand of his not being believed, and yet apprehends these things readily (when they occur) - is he not a man of superior worth?"

passages.zh: 微生畝謂孔子曰：「丘何為是栖栖者與？無乃為佞乎？」
passages.en: Wei Sheng Mu said to Confucius, "Qiu, how is it that you keep roosting about? Is it not that you are an insinuating talker?"

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「非敢為佞也，疾固也。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "I do not dare to play the part of such a talker, but I hate obstinacy."

passages.zh: 子曰：「驥不稱其力，稱其德也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "A horse is called a Ji, not because of its strength, but because of its other good qualities."

passages.zh: 或曰：「以德報怨，何如？」
passages.en: Some one said, "What do you say concerning the principle that injury should be recompensed with kindness?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「何以報德？以直報怨，以德報德。」
passages.en: The Master said, "With what then will you recompense kindness? Recompense injury with justice, and recompense kindness with kindness."

passages.zh: 子曰：「莫我知也夫！」
passages.en: The Master said, "Alas! there is no one that knows me."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「何為其莫知子也？」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "What do you mean by thus saying - that no one knows you?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「不怨天，不尤人。下學而上達。知我者，其天乎！」
passages.en: The Master replied, "I do not murmur against Heaven. I do not grumble against men. My studies lie low, and my penetration rises high. But there is Heaven - that knows me!"

passages.zh: 公伯寮愬子路於季孫。
passages.en: The Gong Bo Liao, having slandered Zi Lu to Ji Sun,

passages.zh: 子服景伯以告，曰：「夫子固有惑志於公伯寮，吾力猶能肆諸市朝。」
passages.en: Zi Fu Jing Bo informed Confucius of it, saying, "Our master is certainly being led astray by the Gong Bo Liao, but I have still power enough left to cut Liao off, and expose his corpse in the market and in the court."

passages.zh: 子曰：「道之將行也與？命也。道之將廢也與？命也。公伯寮其如命何！」
passages.en: The Master said, "If my principles are to advance, it is so ordered. If they are to fall to the ground, it is so ordered. What can the Gong Bo Liao do where such ordering is concerned?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「賢者辟世，其次辟地，其次辟色，其次辟言。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Some men of worth retire from the world. Some retire from particular states. Some retire because of disrespectful looks. Some retire because of contradictory language."

passages.zh: 子曰：「作者七人矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Those who have done this are seven men."

passages.zh: 子路宿於石門。
passages.en: Zi Lu happening to pass the night in Shi Men,

passages.zh: 晨門曰：「奚自？」子路曰：「自孔氏。」
passages.en: the gatekeeper said to him, "Whom do you come from?" Zi Lu said, "From Mr. Kong."

passages.zh: 曰：「是知其不可而為之者與？」
passages.en: "It is he, is it not?" said the other, "who knows the impracticable nature of the times and yet will be doing in them."

passages.zh: 子擊磬於衛。
passages.en: The Master was playing, one day, on a musical stone in Wei,

passages.zh: 有荷蕢而過孔氏之門者，曰：「有心哉！擊磬乎！」
passages.en: when a man, carrying a straw basket, passed the door of the house where Confucius was, and said, "His heart is full who so beats the musical stone."

passages.zh: 既而曰：「鄙哉！硜硜乎！莫己知也，斯己而已矣。
passages.en: A little while after, he added, "How contemptible is the one-ideaed obstinacy those sounds display! When one is taken no notice of, he has simply at once to give over his wish for public employment.

passages.zh: 深則厲，淺則揭。」
passages.en: 'Deep water must be crossed with the clothes on; shallow water may be crossed with the clothes held up.'"

passages.zh: 子曰：「果哉！末之難矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "How determined is he in his purpose! But this is not difficult!"

passages.zh: 子張曰：「《書》云：『高宗諒陰，三年不言。』何謂也？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang said, "When the Shu says that Gao Zong, while observing the usual imperial mourning, was for three years without speaking, what is meant by this?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「何必高宗，古之人皆然。君薨，百官總己以聽於冢宰，三年。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Why must Gao Zong be referred to as an example of this? The ancients all did so. When the sovereign died, the officers all attended to their several duties, taking instructions from the prime minister for three years."

passages.zh: 子曰：「上好禮，則民易使也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "When rulers love to observe the rules of propriety, the people respond readily to the calls on them for service."

passages.zh: 子路問君子。
passages.en: Zi Lu asked what constituted the superior man.

passages.zh: 子曰：「脩己以敬。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The cultivation of himself in reverential carefulness."

passages.zh: 曰：「如斯而已乎？」
passages.en: "And is this all?" said Zi Lu.

passages.zh: 曰：「脩己以安人。」
passages.en: "He cultivates himself so as to give rest to others," was the reply.

passages.zh: 曰：「如斯而已乎？」
passages.en: "And is this all?" again asked Zi Lu.

passages.zh: 曰：「脩己以安百姓。脩己以安百姓，堯舜其猶病諸！」
passages.en: The Master said, "He cultivates himself so as to give rest to all the people. He cultivates himself so as to give rest to all the people - even Yao and Shun were still solicitous about this."

passages.zh: 原壤夷俟。
passages.en: Yuan Rang was squatting on his heels, and so waited the approach of the Master,

passages.zh: 子曰：「幼而不孫弟，長而無述焉，老而不死，是為賊！」
passages.en: who said to him, "In youth not humble as befits a junior; in manhood, doing nothing worthy of being handed down; and living on to old age - this is to be a pest."

passages.zh: 以杖叩其脛。
passages.en: With this he hit him on the shank with his staff.

passages.zh: 闕黨童子將命。
passages.en: A youth of the village of Que was employed by Confucius to carry the messages between him and his visitors.

passages.zh: 或問之曰：「益者與？」
passages.en: Some one asked about him, saying, "I suppose he has made great progress."

passages.zh: 子曰：「吾見其居於位也，見其與先生並行也。
passages.en: The Master said, "I observe that he is fond of occupying the seat of a full-grown man; I observe that he walks shoulder to shoulder with his elders.

passages.zh: 非求益者也，欲速成者也。」
passages.en: He is not one who is seeking to make progress in learning. He wishes quickly to become a man."

passages.zh: 衛靈公問陳於孔子。
passages.en: The duke Ling of Wei asked Confucius about tactics.

passages.zh: 孔子對曰：「俎豆之事，則嘗聞之矣；軍旅之事，未之學也。」
passages.en: Confucius replied, "I have heard all about sacrificial vessels, but I have not learned military matters."

passages.zh: 明日遂行。
passages.en: On this, he took his departure the next day.

passages.zh: 在陳絕糧，從者病，莫能興。
passages.en: When he was in Chen, their provisions were exhausted, and his followers became so ill that they were unable to rise.

passages.zh: 子路慍見曰：「君子亦有窮乎？」
passages.en: Zi Lu, with evident dissatisfaction, said, "Has the superior man likewise to endure in this way?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子固窮，小人窮斯濫矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man may indeed have to endure want, but the mean man, when he is in want, gives way to unbridled license."

passages.zh: 子曰：「賜也，女以予為多學而識之者與？」
passages.en: The Master said, "Ci, you think, I suppose, that I am one who learns many things and keeps them in memory?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「然，非與？」
passages.en: Zi Gong replied, "Yes - but perhaps it is not so?"

passages.zh: 曰：「非也，予一以貫之。」
passages.en: "No," was the answer; "I seek a unity all pervading."

passages.zh: 子曰：「由！知德者鮮矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "You, those who know virtue are few."

passages.zh: 子曰：「無為而治者，其舜也與？
passages.en: The Master said, "May not Shun be instanced as having governed efficiently without exertion?

passages.zh: 夫何為哉，恭己正南面而已矣。」
passages.en: What did he do? He did nothing but gravely and reverently occupy his royal seat."

passages.zh: 子張問行。
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked how a man should conduct himself, so as to be everywhere appreciated.

passages.zh: 子曰：「言忠信，行篤敬，雖蠻貊之邦行矣；言不忠信，行不篤敬，雖州里行乎哉？
passages.en: The Master said, "Let his words be sincere and truthful and his actions honorable and careful - such conduct may be practiced among the rude tribes of the South or the North. If his words be not sincere and truthful, and his actions not honorable and careful, will he, with such conduct, be appreciated, even in his neighborhood?

passages.zh: 立，則見其參於前也；在輿，則見其倚於衡也。
passages.en: When he is standing, let him see those two things, as it were, fronting him. When he is in a carriage, let him see them attached to the yoke.

passages.zh: 夫然後行。」
passages.en: Then may he subsequently carry them into practice."

passages.zh: 子張書諸紳。
passages.en: Zi Zhang wrote these counsels on the end of his sash.

passages.zh: 子曰：「直哉史魚！邦有道，如矢；邦無道，如矢。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Truly straightforward was the historiographer Yu. When good government prevailed in his state, he was like an arrow. When bad government prevailed, he was like an arrow.

passages.zh: 君子哉蘧伯玉！邦有道，則仕；邦無道，則可卷而懷之。」
passages.en: A superior man indeed is Qu Bo Yu! When good government prevails in his state, he is to be found in office. When bad government prevails, he can roll his principles up, and keep them in his breast."

passages.zh: 子曰：「可與言而不與之言，失人；不可與言而與之言，失言。
passages.en: The Master said, "When a man may be spoken with, not to speak to him is to err in reference to the man. When a man may not be spoken with, to speak to him is to err in reference to our words.

passages.zh: 知者不失人，亦不失言。」
passages.en: The wise err neither in regard to their man nor to their words."

passages.zh: 子曰：「志士仁人，無求生以害仁，有殺身以成仁。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The determined scholar and the man of virtue will not seek to live at the expense of injuring their virtue. They will even sacrifice their lives to preserve their virtue complete."

passages.zh: 子貢問為仁。
passages.en: Zi Gong asked about the practice of virtue.

passages.zh: 子曰：「工欲善其事，必先利其器。
passages.en: The Master said, "The mechanic, who wishes to do his work well, must first sharpen his tools.

passages.zh: 居是邦也，事其大夫之賢者，友其士之仁者。」
passages.en: When you are living in any state, take service with the most worthy among its great officers, and make friends of the most virtuous among its scholars."

passages.zh: 顏淵問為邦。
passages.en: Yan Yuan asked how the government of a country should be administered.

passages.zh: 子曰：「行夏之時，乘殷之輅，服周之冕，樂則韶舞。
passages.en: The Master said, "Follow the seasons of Xia. Ride in the state carriage of Yin. Wear the ceremonial cap of Zhou. Let the music be the Shao with its pantomimes.

passages.zh: 放鄭聲，遠佞人。
passages.en: Banish the songs of Zheng, and keep far from specious talkers.

passages.zh: 鄭聲淫，佞人殆。」
passages.en: The songs of Zheng are licentious; specious talkers are dangerous."

passages.zh: 子曰：「人無遠慮，必有近憂。」
passages.en: The Master said, "If a man take no thought about what is distant, he will find sorrow near at hand."

passages.zh: 子曰：「已矣乎！吾未見好德如好色者也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "It is all over! I have not seen one who loves virtue as he loves beauty."

passages.zh: 子曰：「臧文仲其竊位者與？知柳下惠之賢，而不與立也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Was not Zang Wen like one who had stolen his situation? He knew the virtue and the talents of Hui of Liu Xia, and yet did not procure that he should stand with him in court."

passages.zh: 子曰：「躬自厚而薄責於人，則遠怨矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He who requires much from himself and little from others, will keep himself from being the object of resentment."

passages.zh: 子曰：「不曰『如之何如之何』者，吾末如之何也已矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "When a man is not in the habit of saying, 'What shall I think of this? What shall I think of this?' I can indeed do nothing with him!"

passages.zh: 子曰：「群居終日，言不及義，好行小慧，難矣哉！」
passages.en: The Master said, "When a number of people are together, for a whole day, without their conversation turning on righteousness, and when they are fond of carrying out the suggestions of a small shrewdness; theirs is indeed a hard case."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子義以為質，禮以行之，孫以出之，信以成之。
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man in everything considers righteousness to be essential. He performs it according to the rules of propriety. He brings it forth in humility. He completes it with sincerity.

passages.zh: 君子哉！」
passages.en: This is indeed a superior man."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子病無能焉，不病人之不己知也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man is distressed by his want of ability. He is not distressed by men's not knowing him."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子疾沒世而名不稱焉。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man dislikes the thought of his name not being mentioned after his death."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子求諸己，小人求諸人。」
passages.en: The Master said, "What the superior man seeks, is in himself. What the mean man seeks, is in others."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子矜而不爭，群而不黨。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man is dignified, but does not wrangle. He is sociable, but not a partisan."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子不以言舉人，不以人廢言。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man does not promote a man simply on account of his words, nor does he put aside good words because of the man."

passages.zh: 子貢問曰：「有一言而可以終身行之者乎？」
passages.en: Zi Gong asked, saying, "Is there one word which may serve as a rule of practice for all one's life?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「其恕乎！己所不欲，勿施於人。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Is not RECIPROCITY such a word? What you do not want done to yourself, do not do to others."

passages.zh: 子曰：「吾之於人也，誰毀誰譽？
passages.en: The Master said, "In my dealings with men, whose evil do I blame, whose goodness do I praise, beyond what is proper?

passages.zh: 如有所譽者，其有所試矣。
passages.en: If I do sometimes exceed in praise, there must be ground for it in my examination of the individual.

passages.zh: 斯民也，三代之所以直道而行也。」
passages.en: This people supplied the ground why the three dynasties pursued the path of straightforwardness."

passages.zh: 子曰：「吾猶及史之闕文也，有馬者借人乘之。
passages.en: The Master said, "Even in my early days, a historiographer would leave a blank in his text, and he who had a horse would lend him to another to ride.

passages.zh: 今亡矣夫！」
passages.en: Now, alas! there are no such things."

passages.zh: 子曰：「巧言亂德，小不忍則亂大謀。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Specious words confound virtue. Want of forbearance in small matters confounds great plans."

passages.zh: 子曰：「眾惡之，必察焉；眾好之，必察焉。」
passages.en: The Master said, "When the multitude hate a man, it is necessary to examine into the case. When the multitude like a man, it is necessary to examine into the case."

passages.zh: 子曰：「人能弘道，非道弘人。」
passages.en: The Master said, "A man can enlarge the principles which he follows; those principles do not enlarge the man."

passages.zh: 子曰：「過而不改，是謂過矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "To have faults and not to reform them - this, indeed, should be pronounced having faults."

passages.zh: 子曰：「吾嘗終日不食，終夜不寢，以思，無益，不如學也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "I have been the whole day without eating, and the whole night without sleeping; occupied with thinking. It was of no use. The better plan is to learn."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子謀道不謀食。
passages.en: The Master said, "The object of the superior man is truth. Food is not his object.

passages.zh: 耕也，餒在其中矣；學也，祿在其中矣。
passages.en: There is plowing - even in that there is sometimes want. So with learning - emolument may be found in it.

passages.zh: 君子憂道不憂貧。」
passages.en: The superior man is anxious lest he should not get truth; he is not anxious lest poverty should come upon him."

passages.zh: 子曰：「知及之，仁不能守之；雖得之，必失之。
passages.en: The Master said, "When a man's knowledge is sufficient to attain, and his virtue is not sufficient to enable him to hold, whatever he may have gained, he will lose again.

passages.zh: 知及之，仁能守之。不莊以涖之，則民不敬。
passages.en: When his knowledge is sufficient to attain, and he has virtue enough to hold fast, if he cannot govern with dignity, the people will not respect him.

passages.zh: 知及之，仁能守之，莊以涖之。動之不以禮，未善也。」
passages.en: When his knowledge is sufficient to attain, and he has virtue enough to hold fast; when he governs also with dignity, yet if he try to move the people contrary to the rules of propriety - full excellence is not reached."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子不可小知，而可大受也；小人不可大受，而可小知也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man cannot be known in little matters; but he may be intrusted with great concerns. The small man may not be intrusted with great concerns, but he may be known in little matters."

passages.zh: 子曰：「民之於仁也，甚於水火。
passages.en: The Master said, "Virtue is more to man than either water or fire.

passages.zh: 水火，吾見蹈而死者矣，未見蹈仁而死者也。」
passages.en: I have seen men die from treading on water and fire, but I have never seen a man die from treading the course of virtue."

passages.zh: 子曰：「當仁不讓於師。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Let every man consider virtue as what devolves on himself. He may not yield the performance of it even to his teacher."

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子貞而不諒。」
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man is correctly firm, and not firm merely."

passages.zh: 子曰：「事君，敬其事而後其食。」
passages.en: The Master said, "A minister, in serving his prince, reverently discharges his duties, and makes his emolument a secondary consideration."

passages.zh: 子曰：「有教無類。」
passages.en: The Master said, "In teaching there should be no distinction of classes."
