passages.zh: 子曰：「道不同，不相為謀。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Those whose courses are different cannot lay plans for one another."

passages.zh: 子曰：「辭達而已矣。」
passages.en: The Master said, "In language it is simply required that it convey the meaning."

passages.zh: 師冕見，及階，子曰：「階也。」
passages.en: The music master, Mian, having called upon him, when they came to the steps, the Master said, "Here are the steps."

passages.zh: 及席，子曰：「席也。」
passages.en: When they came to the mat for the guest to sit upon, he said, "Here is the mat."

passages.zh: 皆坐，子告之曰：「某在斯，某在斯。」
passages.en: When all were seated, the Master informed him, saying, "So and so is here; so and so is here."

passages.zh: 師冕出。
passages.en: The music master, Mian, having gone out,

passages.zh: 子張問曰：「與師言之道與？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked, saying. "Is it the rule to tell those things to the music master?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「然。固相師之道也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Yes. This is certainly the rule for those who lead the blind."

passages.zh: 季氏將伐顓臾。
passages.en: The head of the Ji family was going to attack Zhuan Yu.

passages.zh: 冉有、季路見於孔子曰：「季氏將有事於顓臾。」
passages.en: Ran You and Ji Lu had an interview with Confucius, and said, "Our chief, Ji, is going to commence operations against Zhuan Yu."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「求！無乃爾是過與？
passages.en: Confucius said, "Qiu, is it not you who are in fault here?

passages.zh: 夫顓臾，昔者先王以為東蒙主，且在邦域之中矣，是社稷之臣也。
passages.en: Now, in regard to Zhuan Yu, long ago, a former king appointed its ruler to preside over the sacrifices to the eastern Mang; moreover, it is in the midst of the territory of our state; and its ruler is a minister in direct connection with the sovereign -

passages.zh: 何以伐為？」
passages.en: What has your chief to do with attacking it?"

passages.zh: 冉有曰：「夫子欲之，吾二臣者皆不欲也。」
passages.en: Ran You said, "Our master wishes the thing; neither of us two ministers wishes it."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「求！周任有言曰：『陳力就列，不能者止。』
passages.en: Confucius said, "Qiu, there are the words of Zhou Ren, 'When he can put forth his ability, he takes his place in the ranks of office; when he finds himself unable to do so, he retires from it.'

passages.zh: 危而不持，顛而不扶，則將焉用彼相矣？
passages.en: How can he be used as a guide to a blind man, who does not support him when tottering, nor raise him up when fallen?'

passages.zh: 且爾言過矣。
passages.en: And further, you speak wrongly.

passages.zh: 虎兕出於柙，龜玉毀於櫝中，是誰之過與？」
passages.en: When a tiger or rhinoceros escapes from his cage; when a tortoise or piece of jade is injured in its repository - whose is the fault?"

passages.zh: 冉有曰：「今夫顓臾，固而近於費。
passages.en: Ran You said, "But at present, Zhuan Yu is strong and near to Fei;

passages.zh: 今不取，後世必為子孫憂。」
passages.en: if our chief do not now take it, it will hereafter be a sorrow to his descendants."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「求！君子疾夫舍曰欲之，而必為之辭。
passages.en: Confucius said. "Qiu, the superior man hates those declining to say 'I want such and such a thing,' and framing explanations for their conduct.

passages.zh: 丘也聞有國有家者，不患寡而患不均，不患貧而患不安。
passages.en: I have heard that rulers of states and chiefs of families are not troubled lest their people should be few, but are troubled lest they should not keep their several places; that they are not troubled with fears of poverty, but are troubled with fears of a want of contented repose among the people in their several places.

passages.zh: 蓋均無貧，和無寡，安無傾。
passages.en: For when the people keep their several places, there will be no poverty; when harmony prevails, there will be no scarcity of people; and when there is such a contented repose, there will be no rebellious upsettings.

passages.zh: 夫如是，故遠人不服，則修文德以來之。
passages.en: So it is. Therefore, if remoter people are not submissive, all the influences of civil culture and virtue are to be cultivated to attract them to be so;

passages.zh: 既來之，則安之。
passages.en: and when they have been so attracted, they must be made contented and tranquil.

passages.zh: 今由與求也，相夫子，遠人不服而不能來也；邦分崩離析而不能守也。
passages.en: Now, here are you, You and Qiu, assisting your chief. Remoter people are not submissive, and, with your help, he cannot attract them to him. In his own territory there are divisions and downfalls, leavings and separations, and, with your help, he cannot preserve it.

passages.zh: 而謀動干戈於邦內。
passages.en: And yet he is planning these hostile movements within the state.

passages.zh: 吾恐季孫之憂，不在顓臾，而在蕭牆之內也。」
passages.en: I am afraid that the sorrow of the Ji Sun family will not be on account of Zhuan Yu, but will be found within the screen of their own court."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「天下有道，則禮樂征伐自天子出；天下無道，則禮樂征伐自諸侯出。
passages.en: Confucius said, "When good government prevails in the empire, ceremonies, music, and punitive military expeditions proceed from the son of Heaven. When bad government prevails in the empire, ceremonies, music, and punitive military expeditions proceed from the princes.

passages.zh: 自諸侯出，蓋十世希不失矣；自大夫出，五世希不失矣；陪臣執國命，三世希不失矣。
passages.en: When these things proceed from the princes, as a rule, the cases will be few in which they do not lose their power in ten generations. When they proceed from the great officers of the princes, as a rule, the case will be few in which they do not lose their power in five generations. When the subsidiary ministers of the great officers hold in their grasp the orders of the state, as a rule the cases will be few in which they do not lose their power in three generations.

passages.zh: 天下有道，則政不在大夫。
passages.en: When right principles prevail in the kingdom, government will not be in the hands of the great officers.

passages.zh: 天下有道，則庶人不議。」
passages.en: When right principles prevail in the kingdom, there will be no discussions among the common people."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「祿之去公室，五世矣；政逮於大夫，四世矣；故夫三桓之子孫，微矣。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "The revenue of the state has left the ducal house now for five generations. The government has been in the hands of the great officers for four generations. On this account, the descendants of the three Huan are much reduced."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「益者三友，損者三友。
passages.en: Confucius said, "There are three friendships which are advantageous, and three which are injurious.

passages.zh: 友直，友諒，友多聞，益矣。
passages.en: Friendship with the uplight; friendship with the sincere; and friendship with the man of much observation - these are advantageous.

passages.zh: 友便辟，友善柔，友便佞，損矣。」
passages.en: Friendship with the man of specious airs; friendship with the insinuatingly soft; and friendship with the glib-tongued - these are injurious."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「益者三樂，損者三樂。
passages.en: Confucius said, "There are three things men find enjoyment in which are advantageous, and three things they find enjoyment in which are injurious.

passages.zh: 樂節禮樂，樂道人之善，樂多賢友，益矣。
passages.en: To find enjoyment in the discriminating study of ceremonies and music; to find enjoyment in speaking of the goodness of others; to find enjoyment in having many worthy friends - these are advantageous.

passages.zh: 樂驕樂，樂佚遊，樂宴樂，損矣。」
passages.en: To find enjoyment in extravagant pleasures; to find enjoyment in idleness and sauntering; to find enjoyment in the pleasures of feasting - these are injurious."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「侍於君子有三愆：言未及之而言謂之躁，言及之而不言謂之隱，未見顏色而言謂之瞽。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "There are three errors to which they who stand in the presence of a man of virtue and station are liable. They may speak when it does not come to them to speak - this is called rashness. They may not speak when it comes to them to speak - this is called concealment. They may speak without looking at the countenance of their superior - this is called blindness."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「君子有三戒：少之時，血氣未定，戒之在色；及其壯也，血氣方剛，戒之在鬭；及其老也，血氣既衰，戒之在得。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "There are three things which the superior man guards against. In youth, when the physical powers are not yet settled, he guards against lust. When he is strong and the physical powers are full of vigor, he guards against quarrelsomeness. When he is old, and the animal powers are decayed, he guards against covetousness."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「君子有三畏：畏天命，畏大人，畏聖人之言。
passages.en: Confucius said, "There are three things of which the superior man stands in awe. He stands in awe of the ordinances of Heaven. He stands in awe of great men. He stands in awe of the words of sages.

passages.zh: 小人不知天命而不畏也，狎大人，侮聖人之言。」
passages.en: The mean man does not know the ordinances of Heaven, and consequently does not stand in awe of them. He is disrespectful to great men. He makes sport of the words of sages."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「生而知之者，上也；學而知之者，次也；困而學之，又其次也；困而不學，民斯為下矣。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "Those who are born with the possession of knowledge are the highest class of men. Those who learn, and so, readily, get possession of knowledge, are the next. Those who are dull and stupid, and yet compass the learning, are another class next to these. As to those who are dull and stupid and yet do not learn - they are the lowest of the people."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「君子有九思：視思明，聽思聰，色思溫，貌思恭，言思忠，事思敬，疑思問，忿思難，見得思義。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "The superior man has nine things which are subjects with him of thoughtful consideration. In regard to the use of his eyes, he is anxious to see clearly. In regard to the use of his ears, he is anxious to hear distinctly. In regard to his countenance, he is anxious that it should be benign. In regard to his demeanor, he is anxious that it should be respectful. In regard to his speech, he is anxious that it should be sincere. In regard to his doing of business, he is anxious that it should be reverently careful. In regard to what he doubts about, he is anxious to question others. When he is angry, he thinks of the difficulties (his anger may involve him in). When he sees gain to be got, he thinks of righteousness."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「見善如不及，見不善如探湯。
passages.en: Confucius said, "Contemplating good, and pursuing it, as if they could not reach it; contemplating evil and shrinking from it, as they would from thrusting the hand into boiling water -

passages.zh: 吾見其人矣，吾聞其語矣。
passages.en: I have seen such men, as I have heard such words.

passages.zh: 隱居以求其志，行義以達其道。
passages.en: Living in retirement to study their aims, and practicing righteousness to carry out their principles -

passages.zh: 吾聞其語矣，未見其人也。」
passages.en: I have heard these words, but I have not seen such men."

passages.zh: 齊景公有馬千駟，死之日，民無德而稱焉。
passages.en: The Duke Jing of Qi had a thousand teams, each of four horses, but on the day of his death, the people did not praise him for a single virtue.

passages.zh: 伯夷叔齊餓于首陽之下，民到于今稱之。
passages.en: Bo Yi and Shu Qi died of hunger at the foot of the Shou Yang mountain, and the people, down to the present time, praise them.

passages.zh: 其斯之謂與？
passages.en: Is not that saying illustrated by this?

passages.zh: 陳亢問於伯魚曰：「子亦有異聞乎？」
passages.en: Chen Kang asked Bo Yu, saying, "Have you heard any lessons from your father different from what we have all heard?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「未也。
passages.en: Bo Yu replied, "No.

passages.zh: 嘗獨立，鯉趨而過庭。
passages.en: He was standing alone once, when I passed below the hall with hasty steps,

passages.zh: 曰：『學詩乎？』
passages.en: and said to me, 'Have you learned the Odes?'

passages.zh: 對曰：『未也。』
passages.en: On my replying 'Not yet,'

passages.zh: 『不學詩，無以言。』
passages.en: he added, 'If you do not learn the Odes, you will not be fit to converse with.'

passages.zh: 鯉退而學詩。
passages.en: I retired and studied the Odes.

passages.zh: 他日又獨立，鯉趨而過庭。
passages.en: Another day, he was in the same way standing alone, when I passed by below the hall with hasty steps,

passages.zh: 曰：『學禮乎？』
passages.en: and said to me, 'Have you learned the rules of Propriety?'

passages.zh: 對曰：『未也。』
passages.en: On my replying 'Not yet,'

passages.zh: 『不學禮，無以立。』
passages.en: he added, 'If you do not learn the rules of Propriety, your character cannot be established.'

passages.zh: 鯉退而學禮。
passages.en: I then retired, and learned the rules of Propriety.

passages.zh: 聞斯二者。」
passages.en: I have heard only these two things from him."

passages.zh: 陳亢退而喜曰：「問一得三，聞詩，聞禮，又聞君子之遠其子也。」
passages.en: Chen Kang retired, and, quite delighted, said, "I asked one thing, and I have got three things. I have heard about the Odes. I have heard about the rules of Propriety. I have also heard that the superior man maintains a distant reserve towards his son."

passages.zh: 邦君之妻，君稱之曰夫人，夫人自稱曰小童；邦人稱之曰君夫人，稱諸異邦曰寡小君；異邦人稱之亦曰君夫人。
passages.en: The wife of the prince of a state is called by him "fu ren". She calls herself "xiao tong". The people of the state call her "jun fu ren", and, to the people of other states, they call her "gua xiao jun". The people of other states also call her "jun fu ren".

passages.zh: 陽貨欲見孔子，孔子不見，歸孔子豚。
passages.en: Yang Huo wished to see Confucius, but Confucius would not go to see him. On this, he sent a present of a pig to Confucius,

passages.zh: 孔子時其亡也，而往拜之，遇諸塗。
passages.en: who, having chosen a time when Huo was not at home, went to pay his respects for the gift. He met him, however, on the way.

passages.zh: 謂孔子曰：「來！予與爾言。」
passages.en: Huo said to Confucius, "Come, let me speak with you."

passages.zh: 曰：「懷其寶而迷其邦，可謂仁乎？」曰：「不可。」
passages.en: He then asked, "Can he be called benevolent who keeps his jewel in his bosom, and leaves his country to confusion?" Confucius replied, "No."

passages.zh: 「好從事而亟失時，可謂知乎？」曰：「不可。」
passages.en: "Can he be called wise, who is anxious to be engaged in public employment, and yet is constantly losing the opportunity of being so?" Confucius again said, "No."

passages.zh: 「日月逝矣，歲不我與。」
passages.en: "The days and months are passing away; the years do not wait for us."

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「諾。吾將仕矣。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "Right; I will go into office."

passages.zh: 子曰：「性相近也，習相遠也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "By nature, men are nearly alike; by practice, they get to be wide apart."

passages.zh: 子曰：「唯上知與下愚不移。」
passages.en: The Master said, "There are only the wise of the highest class, and the stupid of the lowest class, who cannot be changed."

passages.zh: 子之武城，聞弦歌之聲。
passages.en: The Master, having come to Wu Cheng, heard there the sound of stringed instruments and singing.

passages.zh: 夫子莞爾而笑，曰：「割雞焉用牛刀？」
passages.en: Well pleased and smiling, he said, "Why use an ox knife to kill a fowl?"

passages.zh: 子游對曰：「昔者偃也聞諸夫子曰：『君子學道則愛人，小人學道則易使也。』」
passages.en: Zi You replied, "Formerly, Master, I heard you say, 'When the man of high station is well instructed, he loves men; when the man of low station is well instructed, he is easily ruled.'"

passages.zh: 子曰：「二三子！偃之言是也。前言戲之耳。」
passages.en: The Master said, "My disciples, Yan's words are right. What I said was only in sport."

passages.zh: 公山弗擾以費畔，召，子欲往。
passages.en: Gong Shan Fo Rao, when he was holding Fei, and in an attitude of rebellion, invited the Master to visit him, who was rather inclined to go.

passages.zh: 子路不說，曰：「末之也已，何必公山氏之之也。」
passages.en: Zi Lu was displeased, and said, "Indeed, you cannot go! Why must you think of going to see Gong Shan?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「夫召我者而豈徒哉？如有用我者，吾其為東周乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "Can it be without some reason that he has invited me? If any one employ me, may I not make an eastern Zhou?"

passages.zh: 子張問仁於孔子。
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked Confucius about perfect virtue.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「能行五者於天下，為仁矣。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "To be able to practice five things everywhere under heaven constitutes perfect virtue."

passages.zh: 請問之。
passages.en: He begged to ask what they were,

passages.zh: 曰：「恭、寬、信、敏、惠。
passages.en: and was told, "Gravity, generosity of soul, sincerity, earnestness, and kindness.

passages.zh: 恭則不侮，寬則得眾，信則人任焉，敏則有功，惠則足以使人。」
passages.en: If you are grave, you will not be treated with disrespect. If you are generous, you will win all. If you are sincere, people will repose trust in you. If you are earnest, you will accomplish much. If you are kind, this will enable you to employ the services of others."

passages.zh: 佛肸召，子欲往。
passages.en: Bi Xi inviting him to visit him, the Master was inclined to go.

passages.zh: 子路曰：「昔者由也聞諸夫子曰：『親於其身為不善者，君子不入也。』
passages.en: Zi Lu said, "Master, formerly I have heard you say, 'When a man in his own person is guilty of doing evil, a superior man will not associate with him.'

passages.zh: 佛肸以中牟畔，子之往也，如之何！」
passages.en: Bi Xi is in rebellion, holding possession of Zhong Mou; if you go to him, what shall be said?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「然。有是言也。
passages.en: The Master said, "Yes, I did use these words.

passages.zh: 不曰堅乎，磨而不磷；不曰白乎，涅而不緇。
passages.en: But is it not said, that, if a thing be really hard, it may be ground without being made thin? Is it not said, that, if a thing be really white, it may be steeped in a dark fluid without being made black?

passages.zh: 吾豈匏瓜也哉？焉能繫而不食？」
passages.en: Am I a bitter gourd? How can I be hung up out of the way of being eaten?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「由也，女聞六言六蔽矣乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "You, have you heard the six words to which are attached six becloudings?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「未也。」
passages.en: You replied, "I have not."

passages.zh: 「居！吾語女。
passages.en: "Sit down, and I will tell them to you.

passages.zh: 好仁不好學，其蔽也愚；好知不好學，其蔽也蕩；好信不好學，其蔽也賊；好直不好學，其蔽也絞；好勇不好學，其蔽也亂；好剛不好學，其蔽也狂。」
passages.en: There is the love of being benevolent without the love of learning - the beclouding here leads to a foolish simplicity. There is the love of knowing without the love of learning - the beclouding here leads to dissipation of mind. There is the love of being sincere without the love of learning - the beclouding here leads to an injurious disregard of consequences. There is the love of straightforwardness without the love of learning - the beclouding here leads to rudeness. There is the love of boldness without the love of learning - the beclouding here leads to insubordination. There is the love of firmness without the love of learning - the beclouding here leads to extravagant conduct."

passages.zh: 子曰：「小子！何莫學夫詩？
passages.en: The Master said, "My children, why do you not study the Book of Poetry?

passages.zh: 詩，可以興，可以觀，可以群，可以怨。
passages.en: The Odes serve to stimulate the mind. They may be used for purposes of self-contemplation. They teach the art of sociability. They show how to regulate feelings of resentment.

passages.zh: 邇之事父，遠之事君。
passages.en: From them you learn the more immediate duty of serving one's father, and the remoter one of serving one's prince.

passages.zh: 多識於鳥獸草木之名。」
passages.en: From them we become largely acquainted with the names of birds, beasts, and plants."

passages.zh: 子謂伯魚曰：「女為《周南》、《召南》矣乎？
passages.en: The Master said to Bo Yu, "Do you give yourself to the Zhou Nan and the Shao Nan.

passages.zh: 人而不為《周南》、《召南》，其猶正牆面而立也與？」
passages.en: The man who has not studied the Zhou Nan and the Shao Nan is like one who stands with his face right against a wall. Is he not so?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「禮云禮云，玉帛云乎哉？樂云樂云，鐘鼓云乎哉？」
passages.en: The Master said, "'It is according to the rules of propriety,' they say. 'It is according to the rules of propriety,' they say. Are gems and silk all that is meant by propriety? 'It is music,' they say. 'It is music,' they say. Are bells and drums all that is meant by music?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「色厲而內荏，譬諸小人，其猶穿窬之盜也與？」
passages.en: The Master said, "He who puts on an appearance of stern firmness, while inwardly he is weak, is like one of the small, mean people - yea, is he not like the thief who breaks through, or climbs over, a wall?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「鄉原，德之賊也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Your good, careful people of the villages are the thieves of virtue."

passages.zh: 子曰：「道聽而塗說，德之棄也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "To tell, as we go along, what we have heard on the way, is to cast away our virtue."

passages.zh: 子曰：「鄙夫！可與事君也與哉？
passages.en: The Master said, "There are those mean creatures! How impossible it is along with them to serve one's prince!

passages.zh: 其未得之也，患得之；既得之，患失之。
passages.en: While they have not got their aims, their anxiety is how to get them. When they have got them, their anxiety is lest they should lose them.

passages.zh: 苟患失之，無所不至矣。」
passages.en: When they are anxious lest such things should be lost, there is nothing to which they will not proceed."

passages.zh: 子曰：「古者民有三疾，今也或是之亡也。
passages.en: The Master said, "Anciently, men had three failings, which now perhaps are not to be found.

passages.zh: 古之狂也肆，今之狂也蕩；古之矜也廉，今之矜也忿戾；古之愚也直，今之愚也詐而已矣。」
passages.en: The high-mindedness of antiquity showed itself in a disregard of small things; the high-mindedness of the present day shows itself in wild license. The stern dignity of antiquity showed itself in grave reserve; the stern dignity of the present day shows itself in quarrelsome perverseness. The stupidity of antiquity showed itself in straightforwardness; the stupidity of the present day shows itself in sheer deceit."

passages.zh: 子曰：「巧言令色，鮮矣仁。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Fine words and an insinuating appearance are seldom associated with virtue."

passages.zh: 子曰：「惡紫之奪朱也，惡鄭聲之亂雅樂也，惡利口之覆邦家者。」
passages.en: The Master said, "I hate the manner in which purple takes away the luster of vermilion. I hate the way in which the songs of Zheng confound the music of the Ya. I hate those who with their sharp mouths overthrow kingdoms and families."

passages.zh: 子曰：「予欲無言。」
passages.en: The Master said, "I would prefer not speaking."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「子如不言，則小子何述焉？」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "If you, Master, do not speak, what shall we, your disciples, have to record?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「天何言哉？四時行焉，百物生焉，天何言哉？」
passages.en: The Master said, "Does Heaven speak? The four seasons pursue their courses, and all things are continually being produced, but does Heaven say anything?"

passages.zh: 孺悲欲見孔子，孔子辭以疾。
passages.en: Ru Bei wished to see Confucius, but Confucius declined, on the ground of being sick, to see him.

passages.zh: 將命者出戶，取瑟而歌。使之聞之。
passages.en: When the bearer of this message went out at the door, (the Master) took his lute and sang to it, in order that Bei might hear him.

passages.zh: 宰我問：「三年之喪，期已久矣。
passages.en: Zai Wo asked about the three years' mourning for parents, saying that one year was long enough.

passages.zh: 君子三年不為禮，禮必壞；三年不為樂，樂必崩。
passages.en: "If the superior man abstains for three years from the observances of propriety, those observances will be quite lost. If for three years he abstains from music, music will be ruined.

passages.zh: 舊穀既沒，新穀既升，鑽燧改火，期可已矣。」
passages.en: Within a year the old grain is exhausted, and the new grain has sprung up, and, in procuring fire by friction, we go through all the changes of wood for that purpose. After a complete year, the mourning may stop."

passages.zh: 子曰：「食夫稻，衣夫錦，於女安乎？」
passages.en: The Master said, "If you were, after a year, to eat good rice, and wear embroidered clothes, would you feel at ease?"
"I should," replied Wo.

passages.zh: 「女安則為之！
passages.en: The Master said, "If you can feel at ease, do it.

passages.zh: 夫君子之居喪，食旨不甘，聞樂不樂，居處不安，故不為也。
passages.en: But a superior man, during the whole period of mourning, does not enjoy pleasant food which he may eat, nor derive pleasure from music which he may hear. He also does not feel at ease, if he is comfortably lodged. Therefore he does not do what you propose.

passages.zh: 今女安，則為之！」
passages.en: But now you feel at ease and may do it."

passages.zh: 宰我出。
passages.en: Zai Wo then went out,

passages.zh: 子曰：「予之不仁也！
passages.en: and the Master said, "This shows Yu's want of virtue.

passages.zh: 子生三年，然後免於父母之懷。
passages.en: It is not till a child is three years old that it is allowed to leave the arms of its parents.

passages.zh: 夫三年之喪，天下之通喪也。
passages.en: And the three years' mourning is universally observed throughout the empire.

passages.zh: 予也，有三年之愛於其父母乎？」
passages.en: Did Yu enjoy the three years' love of his parents?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「飽食終日，無所用心，難矣哉！
passages.en: The Master said, "Hard is it to deal with who will stuff himself with food the whole day, without applying his mind to anything good!

passages.zh: 不有博弈者乎，為之猶賢乎已。」
passages.en: Are there not gamesters and chess players? To be one of these would still be better than doing nothing at all."

passages.zh: 子路曰：「君子尚勇乎？」
passages.en: Zi Lu said, "Does the superior man esteem valor?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子義以為上。
passages.en: The Master said, "The superior man holds righteousness to be of highest importance.

passages.zh: 君子有勇而無義為亂，小人有勇而無義為盜。」
passages.en: A man in a superior situation, having valor without righteousness, will be guilty of insubordination; one of the lower people having valor without righteousness, will commit robbery."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「君子亦有惡乎？」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "Has the superior man his hatreds also?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「有惡：惡稱人之惡者，惡居下流而訕上者，惡勇而無禮者，惡果敢而窒者。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He has his hatreds. He hates those who proclaim the evil of others. He hates the man who, being in a low station, slanders his superiors. He hates those who have valor merely, and are unobservant of propriety. He hates those who are forward and determined, and, at the same time, of contracted understanding."

passages.zh: 曰：「賜也亦有惡乎？」
passages.en: The Master then inquired, "Ci, have you also your hatreds?"

passages.zh: 「惡徼以為知者，惡不孫以為勇者，惡訐以為直者。」
passages.en: Zi Gong replied, "I hate those who pry out matters, and ascribe the knowledge to their wisdom. I hate those who are only not modest, and think that they are valorous. I hate those who make known secrets, and think that they are straightforward."

passages.zh: 子曰：「唯女子與小人為難養也，近之則不孫，遠之則怨。」
passages.en: The Master said, "Of all people, girls and servants are the most difficult to behave to. If you are familiar with them, they lose their humility. If you maintain a reserve towards them, they are discontented."

passages.zh: 子曰：「年四十而見惡焉，其終也已。」
passages.en: The Master said, "When a man at forty is the object of dislike, he will always continue what he is."

passages.zh: 微子去之，箕子為之奴，比干諫而死。
passages.en: The Viscount of Wei withdrew from the court. The Viscount of Ji became a slave to Zhou. Bi Gan remonstrated with him and died.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：「殷有三仁焉。」
passages.en: Confucius said, "The Yin dynasty possessed these three men of virtue."

passages.zh: 柳下惠為士師，三黜。
passages.en: Hui of Liu Xia, being chief criminal judge, was thrice dismissed from his office.

passages.zh: 人曰：「子未可以去乎？」
passages.en: Some one said to him, "Is it not yet time for you, sir, to leave this?"

passages.zh: 曰：「直道而事人，焉往而不三黜？
passages.en: He replied, "Serving men in an upright way, where shall I go to, and not experience such a thrice-repeated dismissal?

passages.zh: 枉道而事人，何必去父母之邦。」
passages.en: If I choose to serve men in a crooked way, what necessity is there for me to leave the country of my parents?"

passages.zh: 齊景公待孔子，曰：「若季氏則吾不能，以季、孟之閒待之。」
passages.en: The duke Jing of Qi, with reference to the manner in which he should treat Confucius, said, "I cannot treat him as I would the chief of the Ji family. I will treat him in a manner between that accorded to the chief of the Ji, and that given to the chief of the Meng family."

passages.zh: 曰：「吾老矣，不能用也。」
passages.en: He also said, "I am old; I cannot use his doctrines."

passages.zh: 孔子行。
passages.en: Confucius took his departure.

passages.zh: 齊人歸女樂，季桓子受之。
passages.en: The people of Qi sent to Lu a present of female musicians, which Ji Huan received,

passages.zh: 三日不朝，孔子行。
passages.en: and for three days no court was held. Confucius took his departure.

passages.zh: 楚狂接輿歌而過孔子曰：「鳳兮！鳳兮！何德之衰？
passages.en: The madman of Chu, Jie Yu, passed by Confucius, singing and saying, "O Feng! O Feng! How is your virtue degenerated!

passages.zh: 往者不可諫，來者猶可追。
passages.en: As to the past, reproof is useless; but the future may still be provided against.

passages.zh: 已而，已而！今之從政者殆而！」
passages.en: Give up your vain pursuit. Give up your vain pursuit. Peril awaits those who now engage in affairs of government."

passages.zh: 孔子下，欲與之言。
passages.en: Confucius alighted and wished to converse with him,

passages.zh: 趨而辟之，不得與之言。
passages.en: but Jie Yu hastened away, so that he could not talk with him.

passages.zh: 長沮、桀溺耦而耕，孔子過之，使子路問津焉。
passages.en: Chang Zu and Jie Ni were at work in the field together, when Confucius passed by them, and sent Zi Lu to inquire for the ford.

passages.zh: 長沮曰：「夫執輿者為誰？」
passages.en: Chang Zu said, "Who is he that holds the reins in the carriage there?"

passages.zh: 子路曰：「為孔丘。」
passages.en: Zi Lu told him, "It is Kong Qiu."

passages.zh: 曰：「是魯孔丘與？」
passages.en: "Is it not Kong Qiu of Lu?" asked he.

passages.zh: 曰：「是也。」
passages.en: "Yes," was the reply,

passages.zh: 曰：「是知津矣。」
passages.en: to which the other rejoined, "He knows the ford."

passages.zh: 問於桀溺，桀溺曰：「子為誰？」
passages.en: Zi Lu then inquired of Jie Ni, who said to him, "Who are you, sir?"

passages.zh: 曰：「為仲由。」
passages.en: He answered, "I am Zhong You."

passages.zh: 曰：「是魯孔丘之徒與？」
passages.en: "Are you not the disciple of Kong Qiu of Lu?" asked the other.

passages.zh: 對曰：「然。」
passages.en: "I am," replied he,

passages.zh: 曰：「滔滔者天下皆是也，而誰以易之？
passages.en: and then Jie Ni said to him, "Disorder, like a swelling flood, spreads over the whole empire, and who is he that will change its state for you?

passages.zh: 且而與其從辟人之士也，豈若從辟世之士哉？」
passages.en: Rather than follow one who merely withdraws from this one and that one, had you not better follow those who have withdrawn from the world altogether?"

passages.zh: 耰而不輟。
passages.en: With this he fell to covering up the seed, and proceeded with his work, without stopping.

passages.zh: 子路行以告。
passages.en: Zi Lu went and reported their remarks,

passages.zh: 夫子憮然曰：「鳥獸不可與同群，吾非斯人之徒與而誰與？
passages.en: when the Master observed with a sigh, "It is impossible to associate with birds and beasts, as if they were the same with us. If I associate not with these people - with mankind - with whom shall I associate?

passages.zh: 天下有道，丘不與易也。」
passages.en: If right principles prevailed through the empire, there would be no use for me to change its state."

passages.zh: 子路從而後，遇丈人，以杖荷蓧。
passages.en: Zi Lu, following the Master, happened to fall behind, when he met an old man, carrying across his shoulder on a staff a basket for weeds.

passages.zh: 子路問曰：「子見夫子乎？」
passages.en: Zi Lu said to him, "Have you seen my master, sir?"

passages.zh: 丈人曰：「四體不勤，五穀不分。孰為夫子？」
passages.en: The old man replied, "Your four limbs are unaccustomed to toil; you cannot distinguish the five kinds of grain - who is your master?"

passages.zh: 植其杖而芸。
passages.en: With this, he planted his staff in the ground, and proceeded to weed.

passages.zh: 子路拱而立。
passages.en: Zi Lu joined his hands across his breast, and stood before him.

passages.zh: 止子路宿，殺雞為黍而食之，見其二子焉。
passages.en: The old man kept Zi Lu to pass the night in his house, killed a fowl, prepared millet, and feasted him. He also introduced to him his two sons.

passages.zh: 明日，子路行以告。
passages.en: Next day, Zi Lu went on his way, and reported his adventure.

passages.zh: 子曰：「隱者也。」
passages.en: The Master said, "He is a recluse,"

passages.zh: 使子路反見之。
passages.en: and sent Zi Lu back to see him again,

passages.zh: 至則行矣。
passages.en: but when he got to the place, the old man was gone.

passages.zh: 子路曰：「不仕無義。
passages.en: Zi Lu then said to the family, "Not to take office is not righteous.

passages.zh: 長幼之節，不可廢也；君臣之義，如之何其廢之？
passages.en: If the relations between old and young may not be neglected, how is it that he sets aside the duties that should be observed between sovereign and minister?

passages.zh: 欲潔其身，而亂大倫。
passages.en: Wishing to maintain his personal purity, he allows that great relation to come to confusion.

passages.zh: 君子之仕也，行其義也。
passages.en: A superior man takes office, and performs the righteous duties belonging to it.

passages.zh: 道之不行，已知之矣。」
passages.en: As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is aware of that."

passages.zh: 逸民：伯夷、叔齊、虞仲、夷逸、朱張、柳下惠、少連。
passages.en: The men who have retired to privacy from the world have been Bo Yi, Shu Qi, Yu Zhong, Yi Yi, Zhu Zhang, Hui of Liu Xia, and Shao Lian.

passages.zh: 子曰：「不降其志，不辱其身，伯夷、叔齊與！」
passages.en: The Master said, "Refusing to surrender their wills, or to submit to any taint in their persons - such, I think, were Bo Yi and Shu Qi."

passages.zh: 謂：「柳下惠、少連，降志辱身矣。
passages.en: "It may be said of Hui of Liu Xia, and of Shao Lian, that they surrendered their wills, and submitted to taint in their persons,

passages.zh: 言中倫，行中慮，其斯而已矣。」
passages.en: but their words corresponded with reason, and their actions were such as men are anxious to see. This is all that is to be remarked in them."

passages.zh: 謂：「虞仲、夷逸，隱居放言。
passages.en: "It may be said of Yu Zhong and Yi Yi, that, while they hid themselves in their seclusion, they gave a license to their words;

passages.zh: 身中清，廢中權。」
passages.en: but in their persons, they succeeded in preserving their purity, and, in their retirement, they acted according to the exigency of the times."

passages.zh: 「我則異於是，無可無不可。」
passages.en: "I am different from all these. I have no course for which I am predetermined, and no course against which I am predetermined."

passages.zh: 大師摯適齊，亞飯干適楚，三飯繚適蔡，四飯缺適秦。
passages.en: The grand music master, Zhi, went to Qi. Gan, the master of the band at the second meal, went to Chu. Liao, the band master at the third meal, went to Cai. Que, the band master at the fourth meal, went to Qin.

passages.zh: 鼓方叔入於河，播鼗武入於漢，少師陽、擊磬襄，入於海。
passages.en: Fang Shu, the drum master, withdrew to the north of the river. Wu, the master of the hand drum, withdrew to the Han. Yang, the assistant music master, and Xiang, master of the musical stone, withdrew to an island in the sea.

passages.zh: 周公謂魯公曰：「君子不施其親，不使大臣怨乎不以。
passages.en: The duke of Zhou addressed his son, the duke of Lu, saying, "The virtuous prince does not neglect his relations. He does not cause the great ministers to repine at his not employing them.

passages.zh: 故舊無大故，則不棄也。
passages.en: Without some great cause, he does not dismiss from their offices the members of old families.

passages.zh: 無求備於一人。」
passages.en: He does not seek in one man talents for every employment."

passages.zh: 周有八士：伯達、伯適、仲突、仲忽、叔夜、叔夏、季隨、季騧。
passages.en: To Zhou belonged the eight officers, Bo Da, Bo Kuo, Zhong Tu, Zhong Hu, Shu Ye, Shu Xia, Ji Sui, and Ji Gua.

passages.zh: 子張曰：「士見危致命，見得思義，祭思敬，喪思哀，其可已矣。」
passages.en: Zi Zhang said, "The scholar, trained for public duty, seeing threatening danger, is prepared to sacrifice his life. When the opportunity of gain is presented to him, he thinks of righteousness. In sacrificing, his thoughts are reverential. In mourning, his thoughts are about the grief which he should feel. Such a man commands our approbation indeed."

passages.zh: 子張曰：「執德不弘，信道不篤，焉能為有？焉能為亡？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang said, "When a man holds fast to virtue, but without seeking to enlarge it, and believes in right principles, but without firm sincerity, what account can be made of his existence or non-existence?"

passages.zh: 子夏之門人問交於子張。
passages.en: The disciples of Zi Xia asked Zi Zhang about the principles that should characterize mutual intercourse.

passages.zh: 子張曰：「子夏云何？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked, "What does Zi Xia say on the subject?"

passages.zh: 對曰：「子夏曰：『可者與之，其不可者拒之。』」
passages.en: They replied, "Zi Xia says: 'Associate with those who can advantage you. Put away from you those who cannot do so.'"

passages.zh: 子張曰：「異乎吾所聞：君子尊賢而容眾，嘉善而矜不能。
passages.en: Zi Zhang observed, "This is different from what I have learned. The superior man honors the talented and virtuous, and bears with all. He praises the good, and pities the incompetent.

passages.zh: 我之大賢與，於人何所不容？
passages.en: Am I possessed of great talents and virtue? - who is there among men whom I will not bear with?

passages.zh: 我之不賢與，人將拒我，如之何其拒人也？」
passages.en: Am I devoid of talents and virtue? - men will put me away from them. What have we to do with the putting away of others?"

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「雖小道，必有可觀者焉；致遠恐泥，是以君子不為也。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "Even in inferior studies and employments there is something worth being looked at; but if it be attempted to carry them out to what is remote, there is a danger of their proving inapplicable. Therefore, the superior man does not practice them."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「日知其所亡，月無忘其所能，可謂好學也已矣。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "He, who from day to day recognizes what he has not yet, and from month to month does not forget what he has attained to, may be said indeed to love to learn."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「博學而篤志，切問而近思，仁在其中矣。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "There are learning extensively, and having a firm and sincere aim; inquiring with earnestness, and reflecting with self-application - virtue is in such a course."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「百工居肆以成其事，君子學以致其道。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "Mechanics have their shops to dwell in, in order to accomplish their works. The superior man learns, in order to reach to the utmost of his principles."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「小人之過也必文。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "The mean man is sure to gloss his faults."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「君子有三變：望之儼然，即之也溫，聽其言也厲。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "The superior man undergoes three changes. Looked at from a distance, he appears stern; when approached, he is mild; when he is heard to speak, his language is firm and decided."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「君子信而後勞其民，未信則以為厲己也；信而後諫，未信則以為謗己也。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "The superior man, having obtained their confidence, may then impose labors on his people. If he have not gained their confidence, they will think that he is oppressing them. Having obtained the confidence of his prince, one may then remonstrate with him. If he have not gained his confidence, the prince will think that he is vilifying him."

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「大德不踰閑，小德出入可也。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "When a person does not transgress the boundary line in the great virtues, he may pass and repass it in the small virtues."

passages.zh: 子游曰：「子夏之門人小子，當洒掃、應對、進退，則可矣。
passages.en: Zi You said, "The disciples and followers of Zi Xia, in sprinkling and sweeping the ground, in answering and replying, in advancing and receding, are sufficiently accomplished.

passages.zh: 抑末也，本之則無。如之何？」
passages.en: But these are only the branches of learning, and they are left ignorant of what is essential. How can they be acknowledged as sufficiently taught?"

passages.zh: 子夏聞之曰：「噫！言游過矣！
passages.en: Zi Xia heard of the remark and said, "Alas! Yan You is wrong.

passages.zh: 君子之道，孰先傳焉？孰後倦焉？
passages.en: According to the way of the superior man in teaching, what departments are there which he considers of prime importance, and delivers? what are there which he considers of secondary importance, and allows himself to be idle about?

passages.zh: 譬諸草木，區以別矣。
passages.en: But as in the case of plants, which are assorted according to their classes, so he deals with his disciples.

passages.zh: 君子之道，焉可誣也？
passages.en: How can the way of a superior man be such as to make fools of any of them?

passages.zh: 有始有卒者，其惟聖人乎！」
passages.en: Is it not the sage alone, who can unite in one the beginning and the consummation of learning?"

passages.zh: 子夏曰：「仕而優則學，學而優則仕。」
passages.en: Zi Xia said, "The officer, having discharged all his duties, should devote his leisure to learning. The student, having completed his learning, should apply himself to be an officer."

passages.zh: 子游曰：「喪致乎哀而止。」
passages.en: Zi You said, "Mourning, having been carried to the utmost degree of grief, should stop with that."

passages.zh: 子游曰：「吾友張也，為難能也。然而未仁。」
passages.en: Zi You said, "My friend Zhang can do things which are hard to be done, but yet he is not perfectly virtuous."

passages.zh: 曾子曰：「堂堂乎張也，難與並為仁矣。」
passages.en: The philosopher Zeng said, "How imposing is the manner of Zhang! It is difficult along with him to practice virtue."

passages.zh: 曾子曰：「吾聞諸夫子：人未有自致者也，必也親喪乎！」
passages.en: The philosopher Zeng said, "I heard this from our Master: 'Men may not have shown what is in them to the full extent, and yet they will be found to do so, on the occasion of mourning for their parents.'"

passages.zh: 曾子曰：「吾聞諸夫子：孟莊子之孝也，其他可能也；其不改父之臣，與父之政，是難能也。」
passages.en: The philosopher Zeng said, "I have heard this from our Master: 'The filial piety of Meng Zhuang, in other matters, was what other men are competent to, but, as seen in his not changing the ministers of his father, nor his father's mode of government, it is difficult to be attained to.'"

passages.zh: 孟氏使陽膚為士師，問於曾子。
passages.en: The chief of the Meng family having appointed Yang Fu to be chief criminal judge, the latter consulted the philosopher Zeng.

passages.zh: 曾子曰：「上失其道，民散久矣。
passages.en: Zeng said, "The rulers have failed in their duties, and the people consequently have been disorganized, for a long time.

passages.zh: 如得其情，則哀矜而勿喜。」
passages.en: When you have found out the truth of any accusation, be grieved for and pity them, and do not feel joy at your own ability."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「紂之不善，不如是之甚也。
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "Zhou's wickedness was not so great as that name implies.

passages.zh: 是以君子惡居下流，天下之惡皆歸焉。」
passages.en: Therefore, the superior man hates to dwell in a low-lying situation, where all the evil of the world will flow in upon him."

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「君子之過也，如日月之食焉：過也，人皆見之；更也，人皆仰之。」
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "The faults of the superior man are like the eclipses of the sun and moon. He has his faults, and all men see them; he changes again, and all men look up to him."

passages.zh: 衛公孫朝問於子貢曰：「仲尼焉學？」
passages.en: Gong Sun Zhao of Wei asked Zi Gong, saying. "From whom did Zhong Ni get his learning?"

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「文武之道，未墜於地，在人。
passages.en: Zi Gong replied, "The doctrines of Wen and Wu have not yet fallen to the ground. They are to be found among men.

passages.zh: 賢者識其大者，不賢者識其小者，莫不有文武之道焉。
passages.en: Men of talents and virtue remember the greater principles of them, and others, not possessing such talents and virtue, remember the smaller. Thus, all possess the doctrines of Wen and Wu.

passages.zh: 夫子焉不學？而亦何常師之有？」
passages.en: Where could our Master go that he should not have an opportunity of learning them? And yet what necessity was there for his having a regular master?"

passages.zh: 叔孫武叔語大夫於朝，曰：「子貢賢於仲尼。」
passages.en: Shu Sun Wu Shu observed to the great officers in the court, saying, "Zi Gong is superior to Zhong Ni."

passages.zh: 子服景伯以告子貢。
passages.en: Zi Fu Jing Bo reported the observation to Zi Gong,

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「譬之宮牆，賜之牆也及肩，窺見室家之好。
passages.en: who said, "Let me use the comparison of a house and its encompassing wall. My wall only reaches to the shoulders. One may peep over it, and see whatever is valuable in the apartments.

passages.zh: 夫子之牆數仞，不得其門而入，不見宗廟之美，百官之富。
passages.en: The wall of my Master is several fathoms high. If one do not find the door and enter by it, he cannot see the ancestral temple with its beauties, nor all the officers in their rich array.

passages.zh: 得其門者或寡矣。
passages.en: But I may assume that they are few who find the door.

passages.zh: 夫子之云，不亦宜乎！」
passages.en: Was not the observation of the chief only what might have been expected?"

passages.zh: 叔孫武叔毀仲尼。
passages.en: Shu Sun Wu Shu having spoken revilingly of Zhong Ni,

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「無以為也，仲尼不可毀也。
passages.en: Zi Gong said, "It is of no use doing so. Zhong Ni cannot be reviled.

passages.zh: 他人之賢者，丘陵也，猶可踰也；仲尼，日月也，無得而踰焉。
passages.en: The talents and virtue of other men are hillocks and mounds which may be stepped over. Zhong Ni is the sun or moon, which it is not possible to step over.

passages.zh: 人雖欲自絕，其何傷於日月乎？多見其不知量也！」
passages.en: Although a man may wish to cut himself off from the sage, what harm can he do to the sun or moon? He only shows that he does not know his own capacity."

passages.zh: 陳子禽謂子貢曰：「子為恭也，仲尼豈賢於子乎？」
passages.en: Chen Zi Qin, addressing Zi Gong, said, "You are too modest. How can Zhong Ni be said to be superior to you?"

passages.zh: 子貢曰：「君子一言以為知，一言以為不知，言不可不慎也。
passages.en: Zi Gong said to him, "For one word a man is often deemed to be wise, and for one word he is often deemed to be foolish. We ought to be careful indeed in what we say.

passages.zh: 夫子之不可及也，猶天之不可階而升也。
passages.en: Our Master cannot be attained to, just in the same way as the heavens cannot be gone up by the steps of a stair.

passages.zh: 夫子之得邦家者，所謂立之斯立，道之斯行，綏之斯來，動之斯和。
passages.en: Were our Master in the position of the ruler of a state or the chief of a family, we should find verified the description which has been given of a sage's rule: he would plant the people, and forthwith they would be established; he would lead them on, and forthwith they would follow him; he would make them happy, and forthwith multitudes would resort to his dominions; he would stimulate them, and forthwith they would be harmonious.

passages.zh: 其生也榮，其死也哀，如之何其可及也。」
passages.en: While he lived, he would be glorious. When he died, he would be bitterly lamented. How is it possible for him to be attained to?"

passages.zh: 堯曰：「咨！爾舜！天之曆數在爾躬。
passages.en: Yao said, "Oh! you, Shun, the Heaven-determined order of succession now rests in your person.

passages.zh: 允執其中。
passages.en: Sincerely hold fast the due Mean.

passages.zh: 四海困窮，天祿永終。」
passages.en: If there shall be distress and want within the four seas, the Heavenly revenue will come to a perpetual end."

passages.zh: 舜亦以命禹。
passages.en: Shun also used the same language in giving charge to You.

passages.zh: 曰：「予小子履，敢用玄牡，敢昭告于皇皇后帝：有罪不敢赦。
passages.en: Tang said, "I, the child Lu, presume to use a dark-colored victim, and presume to announce to Thee, O most great and sovereign God, that the sinner I dare not pardon,

passages.zh: 帝臣不蔽，簡在帝心。
passages.en: and thy ministers, O God, I do not keep in obscurity. The examination of them is by thy mind, O God.

passages.zh: 朕躬有罪，無以萬方；萬方有罪，罪在朕躬。」
passages.en: If, in my person, I commit offenses, they are not to be attributed to you, the people of the myriad regions. If you in the myriad regions commit offenses, these offenses must rest on my person."

passages.zh: 周有大賚，善人是富。
passages.en: Zhou conferred great gifts, and the good were enriched.

passages.zh: 「雖有周親，不如仁人。
passages.en: "Although he has his near relatives, they are not equal to my virtuous men.

passages.zh: 百姓有過，在予一人。」
passages.en: The people are throwing blame upon me, the One man."

passages.zh: 謹權量，審法度，修廢官，四方之政行焉。
passages.en: He carefully attended to the weights and measures, examined the body of the laws, restored the discarded officers, and the good government of the kingdom took its course.

passages.zh: 興滅國，繼絕世，舉逸民，天下之民歸心焉。
passages.en: He revived states that had been extinguished, restored families whose line of succession had been broken, and called to office those who had retired into obscurity, so that throughout the kingdom the hearts of the people turned towards him.

passages.zh: 所重：民、食、喪、祭。
passages.en: What he attached chief importance to were the food of the people, the duties of mourning, and sacrifices.

passages.zh: 寬則得眾，信則民任焉，敏則有功，公則說。
passages.en: By his generosity, he won all. By his sincerity, he made the people repose trust in him. By his earnest activity, his achievements were great. By his justice, all were delighted.

passages.zh: 子張問於孔子曰：「何如斯可以從政矣？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang asked Confucius, saying, "In what way should a person in authority act in order that he may conduct government properly?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「尊五美，屏四惡，斯可以從政矣。」
passages.en: The Master replied, "Let him honor the five excellent, and banish away the four bad, things; then may he conduct government properly."

passages.zh: 子張曰：「何謂五美？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang said, "What are meant by the five excellent things?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「君子惠而不費，勞而不怨，欲而不貪，泰而不驕，威而不猛。」
passages.en: The Master said, "When the person in authority is beneficent without great expenditure; when he lays tasks on the people without their repining; when he pursues what he desires without being covetous; when he maintains a dignified ease without being proud; when he is majestic without being fierce."

passages.zh: 子張曰：「何謂惠而不費？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang said, "What is meant by being beneficent without great expenditure?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「因民之所利而利之，斯不亦惠而不費乎？
passages.en: The Master replied, "When the person in authority makes more beneficial to the people the things from which they naturally derive benefit - is not this being beneficent without great expenditure?

passages.zh: 擇可勞而勞之，又誰怨？
passages.en: When he chooses the labors which are proper, and makes them labor on them, who will repine?

passages.zh: 欲仁而得仁，又焉貪？
passages.en: When his desires are set on benevolent government, and he secures it, who will accuse him of covetousness?

passages.zh: 君子無眾寡，無小大，無敢慢，斯不亦泰而不驕乎？
passages.en: Whether he has to do with many people or few, or with things great or small, he does not dare to indicate any disrespect - is not this to maintain a dignified ease without any pride?

passages.zh: 君子正其衣冠，尊其瞻視，儼然人望而畏之，斯不亦威而不猛乎？」
passages.en: He adjusts his clothes and cap, and throws a dignity into his looks, so that, thus dignified, he is looked at with awe - is not this to be majestic without being fierce?"

passages.zh: 子張曰：「何謂四惡？」
passages.en: Zi Zhang then asked, "What are meant by the four bad things?"

passages.zh: 子曰：「不教而殺謂之虐；不戒視成謂之暴；慢令致期謂之賊；猶之與人也，出納之吝，謂之有司。」
passages.en: The Master said, "To put the people to death without having instructed them - this is called cruelty. To require from them, suddenly, the full tale of work, without having given them warning - this is called oppression. To issue orders as if without urgency, at first, and, when the time comes, to insist on them with severity - this is called injury. And, generally, in the giving pay or rewards to men, to do it in a stingy way - this is called acting the part of a mere official."

passages.zh: 子曰：「不知命，無以為君子也。
passages.en: The Master said, "Without recognizing the ordinances of Heaven, it is impossible to be a superior man.

passages.zh: 不知禮，無以立也。
passages.en: Without an acquaintance with the rules of Propriety, it is impossible for the character to be established.

passages.zh: 不知言，無以知人也。」
passages.en: Without knowing the force of words, it is impossible to know men."
